content:
8, 2016
TL;DRF2P is a Demo-Mode only. Solid hunting game with detailed hunting grounds, cheap MMO-like payment model, rare but large actual content updates but loads of optional microtransaction material.F2P and Payment modelThe F2P content contains the license to hunt Whitetail Deer, Pheasant and three kinds of Rabbit only. As of the latest major Patch you now get a shotgun for free as well, so the grindwall for hunting the rabbits and pheasant is gone. One ingame currency "GMS" can be obtained by doing missions like "Track a Mule Deer", "Harvest a Mule Deer", "Spot a Whitetail Deer". Its a pretty useless currency though.The payment model lets you pay per month in order to get a license for all animals, so think of it as a "cheap MMO-type payment". However in contrast to MMOs, actual content updates to be played by you as a license holder appear only a few times a year. On the other hand these updates usually contain a new hunting reserve with new animals, so they offer quite some content.There are a lot of weekly minor updates with new guns, clothes and other equipment not really needed for playing the game though.The GameIn my opinion thehunter is a well-made hunting simulator with decent animal behavior and very well made highly detailed hunting reserves.The negative points I want to mention are random fps-drops in certain areas of the map which many players seem to encounter, "old animals" seem a bit lacking in texture quality compared to the new ones as well as "old reserves" are not as diverse and different from each other as the more recent ones. Some reserves are considered lackluster by a majority of the playerbase due to "recycling" of animals, e.g. the Australia reserve only contains the kangaroo as a specifically australian animal.Some content patches in the past caused problems for players to connect in multiplayer games.How much does it cost ?If there is no sale going I can not recommend buying a membership via the Ingame Store at all. Instead, I highly recommend to get the DVD Version of 2013 for ~10 € which is a far better deal.Basically this DVD Version comes with everything you need in contrast to the ingame-store sets. Even if you want to extend your membership, the DVDs offer much more. For some animals, callers are quite handy, so you might want to plan another ~10€ for callers. For fox and coyote I think the "Jackrabbit caller" is essential, for the rest of the callers you dont own it is really dependant on your playstyle. The same goes for any more "advanced" hunting clothing.To summarize, I think buying a DVD-Version which offers a fair deal, if you can not get the 2013 Version you will need ~5€ for a decent big-game hunting rifle, depending on the ongoing sales.Important:Do not buy any of the starter packs unless the largest one gets a hefty discount on Steam, because the other ones will leave you with the lack of a big-game rifle as well and are lackluster in value proposition compared to buying any DVD Version.One thing that should be mentioned here is goose and duck hunting. Though you can find those animals without any special equipment, you will need this equipment should you want to hunt birds in large scale.Since geese and ducks require dummies and a special hunting setup you need ~15 €, depending on the current sales for a goose or a duck setup, so these act as "DLCs".AlternativesMost of the "Cabelas" Hunting  games are just mass animals shooters, the "Cabelas Big Game Hunter Pro Hunts" is not bad though, just simplified mechanics.If you enjoy the detailed landscape and the "slow" gameplay, you might want to look into "Fishing Planet". This one actual is true F2P, but comes with a high grindwall.

content:
24, 2016
												I have played this game off and on over the many years it's been promoted and advertised.This is a fenced in game riddled with micro transactions that require you to spend money to get new items and gear along with actual Hunting licenses as a Monthly Subscription.I am not a Fan of the Micro store requiring actual money, but they do offer missions to get consumables through in game currency for hunting contracts. Granted, the game is enjoyable as a Hunting simulator and challenging. But, the game has evolved since I first started playing.Beta (2009): free to play limited to 10 bullets and Mule dear for hunting only2012: free to play limited to only Mule dear Hunting only with unlimited ammo2016: free to play limited to a rotation of various animals for hunting *at time of review still needed to playI am going back to the game during different times of spurts for hunting enjoyment, but from past experience you will always need a hunting buddy with plenty of equipment for a well rounded enjoyment on many of the Hunting Maps available. *NOTE* I will be updating this review after I play through this years newest content.*Edit 9/03/2016* : OK the game still requires guests to miss out on alot of things, but with the rotation of different huntable animals it does allow for those that still want to hunt with out paying a Chance to partake in hunting.Now if you wanted to see what I am talking about I have done a Stream with a Buddy of mine and the first 30 minutes should help shed some light on the game play as a Guest.- Also to note later on the guest gamers ended up getting Starter Packs to allow for unlimited hunting of any and all animals.


YouTube™ Video: Hunting with Hyjinks and JackDaniels (Day 1) 

			Views: 66		

			-- Watch live at https://www.twitch.tv/jherb325 Name of the game is 'theHunter" Its a Free to Play game with Plenty of Micro Transactions.		

- The Newest addition of Dog's is a Nice addition that was a LONG time coming. Granted you still have to train your hunting companion through the actions you need them for.- Guest Rotation of Hunting changes the type of Animals you can hunt every week on Thursday, During the time of the Video it was limited to Water Fowl as the new rotation Free hunt.- You can still attempt to complete missions for in game currency but you will still only be able to spend them on Consumable Items.- Every beginner to this game will always have questions that might take some time to learn. There is a Wiki Page that was put together by the community to help with virtually anything you can think of related to the game. - - Shopping - - Equipment - - Hunting recommendations - - etc.Please take a Chance to check it out if your having trouble with your decision on spending money on the hunter.http://thehunter.wikia.com/wiki/The_Hunter_WikiaThe wiki will help even further if your not sure on equipment purchasing, for the type of hunter you would like to try and become or focus on.http://thehunter.wikia.com/wiki/Buying_Guide*edit*If there is something that is not helpful about the review let me know in the Comment's, so I can help you further.Nominated this game for the Steam awards.

												I have been searching for a good hunting game for awhile now and this gem popped up. Its a beautifully crafted game and you can tell there was love put into it. It is a solid title, however, I cannot enjoy the Hunter because I am constantly stopped by pay walls with it. Microtransactions are abundant and the game takes the fun out of it being a video game by making you have to pay for (like in real life) rounds, rifles, pistols, holsters, hunting licenses (which are temporary) and all sorts of other manner of hunting equipment as well.Its a great game, it could use vehicles, but the major downside is how all the equipment is blocked by constant cash fees. You can't just go out there and hunt whatever you like without paying the developer something and that is definetaly not what I am looking for in a hunting simulator. I will say you start with some basic equipment and are able to hunt hare and whitetail deer (correct me if I am wrong).I could understand and appreciate mechanics that dealt with ingame currency by rewarding you with cash for trophy kills, but that is not the case. I wish this was a standalone title, but sadly it is not. There is a multiplayer aspect to it and I really did not delve into it. If this is a MMO-like/multiplayer game with a deep community I could slightly understand the microtranscation fees. I still however in my good conscience cannot reccommend this game. If there is a standalone version where I can just buy the whole product and am not blocked by microtranscations, I would gladly pay for it. It would be well worth it in my honest opinion, but until that point this game is a no from me.

content:
r 23, 2014
This review mostly discusses the main issue the game has for most people – the pricing model. If you are looking for a gameplay or more balanced review, please Google for a “Let’s play” video or read another review instead. The positive recommendation only applies if you deem the pricing model as discussed acceptable.First things first - This title is not Free to Play.If you are looking for a free to play hunting title i have to start this review with some bad news: this game is not free to play by most interpretations of the term "Free to play". As a limited member you can do the following:  You can enter all the reserves and wander around. You receive one basic rifle, a scope and unlimited ammunition refills for that rifle. You will also receive a deer caller. You can only hunt Cottontail rabbits and Mule Deers. Hunting all other animals is prohibited in the sense that you cannot do so at all. You can see them, but shooting them is not possible.Unlike other free to play games you cannot feasibly unlock new content by playing the game a lot or by being good at it. You are stuck with what you have and that is it – and it’s admittedly not too much. The pricing model.So, you made it past the initial post explaining the game is not free to play and might be considering picking the game up? In that case, let us talk about the games pricing model and what it entails. The games pricing model is twofold: there are both subscriptions and items purchases. Subscription:  Subscription starts at 9.99 for a 3 month period which is arguably quite good compared to most MMO's. In exchange for your subscription you will receive unlimited ammunition for all the weapons you own, and a license to hunt all species of animals in the game. It is also possible to buy ammunition and animal hunting licenses as separate items though the monetary exchange rate for this is fairly bad in comparison. (But perhaps worthwhile if you are a very casual player)Items: Buyable items cover a broad range of possibilities. There is weapons, scopes, clothing, deployables (Hunting towers), utilities (Animal callers, storage increasing backpack) and temporally power-ups (Wind indicators, facial paint et cetera).Except for the power-ups all items are permanent once bought, with the caveat being that you will need an animal license and ammunition to hunt specific animals. There is an additional caveat as well: Each weapon can only be used on a subset of the animals in the game - you cannot use a pistol on a bear or a rifle on a pheasant for example. If you want to hunt all animals you will need to buy multiple weapons. The utilities sold are somewhat more optional though a huge convenience: callers enable you to coax animals them out of hiding or locate them, while specific clothing will provide superior camouflage thus fewer running animals as you try to sneak upon them.Bottom line? Expect to buy a membership and - depending on playing preference - one or more weapons, scopes and clothing if you wish to fully enjoy everything the game has to offer. The cheapest variety would be buying the wayfarer pack for about 15 Euro's; this includes 3 months of membership, a shotgun, a pistol with scope and some consumables. The shotgun itself is - with different ammo types - able to take down every type of animal in the game. Alternative you can do some research and find yourself a relatively cheap combination of items that allows you to hunt virtually everything the way you want it. Still, don't be surprised if you end up forking 20-30 bucks over initially if you chose this route (that figure includes a 3 month membership). Final thoughts.Despite the games price model arguably being steep I personally find myself enjoying the game quite a bit, so for me it is well worth the triple-a equivalent price I spend on it so far. Considering my current time invested, the subscription fee and my lack of a need to buy new items the game will be cheaper than a regular subscription MMO if I keep playing it another month or two, while spending a similar amount of time on it.That said: I can only advice the game to people who – like me – enjoy hunting simulations quite a bit. If you plan on picking up the game you should be able to live with the thought of having to possibly do a relatively sizable investment initially, followed by a fairly mild recurrent billing scheme. It is not a good pickup for people looking exclusively for a free to play title due to the rather sharp limitations and the inability to unlock content by playing a lot or being good. Still, the game itself is a lot of fun if you like hunting sims. If you can stomach the need for payment and don't mind doing some research into the items you want i can hearthily recomment it.Addendum - How to make the most out of your game without paying a dime: There is an excellent guide on the forums by Maverick that discusses the topic of getting the most out of the game without paying a dime for it. The method discussed will not grant access to all content indefinitely: You will be reliant on missions and counting your bullets. Even so it will allow you to access more content (Including hunting other animals) on a temporary basis. If you are strapped for cash but really want to play more of the game the suggestions in it may be a viable alternative - at least for a while.

												Atmospheric and beautiful FPS where you're not shooting terrorists, zombies, aliens, demons or even dinosaurs. This time... it's bears. Bears, elks, pheasants and other wildlife roam the wilderness for you to track and hunt down for that perfect trophy. Gorgeous nature scenery and a wide variety of weapons keep the shooting fresh and relaxing.This game is one of the best examples of combination of realistic graphics with amazing gameplay. The game perfectly conveys the atmosphere of the hunt, level of interaction with the environment is extremely high. "theHunter" impresses with its proximity to the reality and the different variations of action.The game is free to play. If you are not a member, you can hunt 5 species for free a week. 2 of the 5 species are always the same, but 2 species change every week so you get a chance to hunt all animals. It is a simulation, so it is important for the player to take the right ammo when going on a hunt, otherwise some shots will be disallowed(Company promotes ethical hunting).

number of helpful: 21 of 28 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
3, 2016
												Let me just start off by stating that I’m giving a positive rating because I think TheHunter is a decent game, but despite this I’m going to get pretty negative in this review, mostly because it’s essentially one very long complaint of a problem that I think is crippling to the game. I’m also not going to summarize how the core game works at all, so if you’re looking for a review of that then this probably won’t help much.As you can probably already see from the Steam reviews, there’s been a lot of controversy about Thehunter’s Free 2 Play model. I never had much experience with this, as I started out paying for membership, but the controversy eventually led Expansive Worlds to revise their model to a slightly less intrusive one, but asides from the confirmation that is was indeed a pretty bad model I think that maybe a lot of the negative reviews are undeserved.In general I think that periodical charges are perfectly reasonable in a game which offers continuous updates and new content, and TheHunter is one of the better hunting games in a video game genre otherwise marred by some pretty embarrassing design standards. It should be pretty clear from my playtime here on Steam that I like it. Despite a visible need for polish in terms of the games UI design and how the game conveys important information, as well as a pretty ♥♥♥♥ decision to make everything including the launcher fully dependant on Expansive Worlds’ servers (which means that when there’s problems on their end you can’t play the game at all, not even singleplayer, and sometimes a host can lose connection to her or his own game). However, the main problem that I’ve chosen to write about in this review stems from how the ingame store operates.For all means and purposes, TheHunter is a stealth game where the primary goal is to kill animals. In a stealth game about killing things, what are some of the general design elements that are the most crucial to providing variety and thereby prolonged engagement, i.e. fun, to the experience? Well, having different environments to play in and having different ways to kill things.If you pay for membership, (or if you use in-game currency to buy permissions for hunting different animals) you’re provided with the rudimentary means to hunt all animals within all 10 different reserves, and the environments of the different reserves do impact the difficulty of the game and the way you have to play in order to hunt efficiently, so in that case the game fulfills the first of those requirements.There’s also a large variety of different weapons to use and different equipment to use, and they all impact the way you can hunt significantly. Some weapons are silent, some weapons are light, some weapons are powerful and heavy, and you can get hunting blinds, bait, camouflage clothing, dogs, bows, and all other sorts of cool stuff to hunt animals in different ways,-BUT ALL OF THAT COSTS MONEY.-Like most Free 2 Play multiplayer games with microtransactions, there’s two kinds of currency, gm$, earned by completing missions ingame, and em$, earned by paying for it with real money. What is different and ironically worse than the microtransactions of most other Free 2 Play multiplayer games is that the stuff which can actually be bought with gm$ is currently limited to only the absolutely most pitifully uninteresting consumables that the game has to offer;You cannot buy weapons with gm$. You cannot buy tents or hunting blinds with gm$. You cannot buy bait barrels, which are required to use bait, with gm$. You cannot buy dogs with gm$. You cannot buy clothing with gm$. You cannot buy scopes with gm$.Essentially, any digital items which are permanently added to your character, or which actually do something significant to the gameplay requires payments in addition to your membership subscription, which to me is much more significant assery than the notorious former Free 2 Play structure. The concept of having to buy ingame equipment in order to have fun in a game that you’re already supporting through periodical charges is ludicrous.TheHunters main equivalent of points in its semi-competitive community high-score system is HunterScore, which is rewarded for getting ingame milestone achievements, like “25 Mule Deer harvests” or “100 .243 bolt action rifle harvests”. There is a maximum limit to the HunterScore which can be achieved, but since getting there requires killing animals with all weapons in the game, including those which cost money, it effectively acts as a Pay 2 Win structure if you really want to spend the ridiculous amount of time it requires to actually compete with the top players.The problems of the cost structure are slightly alleviated by the retail packages, which in some areas are actually way cheaper and offer more value than just buying membership online. With my first retail package I felt that I was getting significantly more value for my money than the 14.99€ “Wayfarer” starter package I bought on Steam, and this led me to later buy a couple of other packages from a german website in order to get some more new equipment and some added membership time. This time it was far less of a satisfying purchase, though, partly because it was less cheap and partly because only the membership and the single “special edition” weapon I got from the packages was actually useful to me. Most equipment offered in the retail packages is the same as every other retail package, save for usually one “exclusive” premium item, usually a weapon.You can stack multiple pieces of the same equipment in TheHunter, but it seems like an oversight much more than anything else, because you can’t actually do anything with spare pieces of equipment. There’s no trading system, you can’t sell them for a bit of money, and there’s no point of having two of the same gun with you on a hunt since you’re limited to the same amount of ammunition as when you’re carrying one anyways. If anything they do make navigating your inventory more tedious, because you’ll eventually see, like, 6 .243 bolt action rifles and 6 12 gauge single shot shotguns because you’ve activated 5 different packages which all contained roughly the same guns and because there isn’t even any option to discard them. In fact, with one of the recent updates the 12 gauge single shot shotgun is now the only weapon in the store which costs 0 em$, so just for ♥♥♥♥♥ and giggles I bought 100 and now my ingame inventory is cluttered with them.Anyways, now that I got the retail packages from Germany and activated them, I haven’t really ended up feeling like I made a good purchase. Instead, I really feel like a gullible idiot, and probably rightfully so. It’s mostly this feeling which is the reason as to why I’m writing this review in the first place. The weapons in TheHunter are only digital trinkets after all, and I don’t think it’s right to spend money on digital trinkets like this in the first place. I don’t understand the need for it either, if it was possible to at least also buy weapons for gm$ in addition to em$, it would provide a major incentive for players to keep playing the game, and since membership requires a subscription already, then what’s the problem?Shouldn’t the membership subscriptions be paying for the maintenance and content updates of the game so that these seemingly kind of greedy and seemingly unnecessary micro transactions wouldn’t be needed? What’s the point of having two separate payment systems operating in the same game?I like the game, but looking at the store really just makes me annoyed. After the tremendous amount of negative reviews following the former Free 2 Play model, though, they did revise it in the end. Maybe one of the next priorities could be revising the payment system?

content:
4, 2016
												Ok we'll try keep this short and simple. Yes this game CAN cost a lot of money (I've put in around $500 USD just because I enjoy it and my financial status allows me to) to play but there are lots of things you can do for 100% free. First off do the missions they give you gm$ which can in turn be used to buy ammo, camping supplies, licenses, and a lot of other stuff.    After you get enough gm$ buy a license for a different animal which you can then activate the missions which require you to kill said animal (if you don't have the weapon needed for the mission just ask players that do have that gun many will be glad to help you.) Oh and some missions can be done by just tracking or spotting an animal so theres some gm$ you can get and not have to buy a license. I would buy the Trailrunner membership it gives you tons of things like weapons, camoflauge, scopes, calls, stands, tents, camping supplies, etc. Along with a memebrship to hunt all animals ingame for one year. The cost for the trailrunner is $49.99 USD which equates to 7 cents a day (rounded) It costs more to live per day than it does to play an awesome game!    Oh and after your year is up if you decide to keep on playing, the basic one year memebrship costs $34.99 USD and you still get to hunt all the animals and you get 3 of the deployable hunting stands. Another thing is that 90% of the negative reviews never put at least 50 hours in the game they play for 10 minutes then cry because the game isn't free to play. Another thing you can do to earn em$ is the "earn em$" option where you watch videos, read articles, download stuff (I do not recommend you download stuff unless you're a betting man) I have some friends which only play by this method and are quite effective at it.    Oh and for the waterfowl it does cost a lot and i do not recommend it I only hunt them a couple times a year so save your money and look for someone who already has a setup. This game is also very realistic there are more animals than in real life but the developers needed to make this game a bit more fun, which they did perfectly. This is why I recommend this game, if you need help with anything ingame add me on theHunter at Charlielolyoloswag I've been playing for a bit over a year.  Also the devs recently did a lot for their Free to play memebers they gave them 5 new species to hunt 2 of which switch every week, and they gave us all the Single Shot shotgun with free ammo for it. So much for making this short and simple haha :)

r 4, 2016
												The game is beautiful and the animals are pretty realistic, the immersion is great. However the economics of the game are fundamentally broken. In order to hunt and enjoy you need to spend a lot of money, real money. Before anyone jumps to conclusions I should make it clear that i have already spent 57 EUROS (more then 60$)  on this game. Because it wouldn't allow me to hunt anything I've purchased a 50 euro annual membership, i chose that one because it also gave me alot of ingame items and I'm comfortable spending that amount on a game. OK. I got some things like weapons, clothing, a tent, a caller or something. After I have spent some time in the game I realized that even that won't be enough. I spent another 7 EUROS for a crossbow and some callers/lures. Now I'm at the point where i realize that even though i have spent this amount of money I won't be able to enjoy all the features of the game without spending further money. But you see I am not comfortable spending any more money on this game and if any of the developers are reading the review, i will tell you this: I WON'T SPEND ANY FURTHER MONEY ON YOUR GAME. EVER. In fact i won't even play because i just can't enjoy a game that has no progression, a game that i know that no matter what i do ingame i will never be able to unlock items without paying for them. And playing without those items is possible but is artificially made harder in order to trick you into buying them.As someone said in another review theHunter is the perfect example of what is wrong with today's gaming. Some people believe that everyone is a millionaire and can afford to spend 500 EUROS on a game. I repeat i am perfectly fine spending 50 EUROS on a game (buying it outright) but I won't be someone's milk machine.

												Looking a gift horse in the mouth is your passion? Welcome to the review section of theHunter:"home of the reviewing cheeky brats"I´ve just browsed those negative reviews and looked for some criticism beyond the popular "mememeeep, but it´s labeled free and there´s stuff I´d have to pay for". The devs gave a lot more content to those free-players in the last weeks (at least 5 free species with a weekly rotation, enough weapons to hunt everything, special competitions for non-members) and all new reviews still concentrate on "not free to play"!It´s remarkable that giving the basic access to a game away for free is leading to bad reviews. Most reviewers got less than 50 hrs ig and are just annoyed that they aren´t gifted the complete package. We are talking about steam users. The concept to pay for games isn´t exactely unknown on steam. Take Fallout 4: just to try the game you have to pay 50 bucks and if you don´t like it it´s a case of tough luck. It started in November 15 and until now there´s DLC for another 70 bucks to be bought. To enjoy the whole game you´ve got to empty your wallet regularly. Any complaints about that rip-off in the review section? No, since you´d have to admit that you´ve paid 50 bucks just to witness that you´re excluded from large parts of the game until you pay 70 more bucks.10 days ago the devs of theHunter released a patch that solved a lot of problems. Since then the game´s been running stable (even with 4k settings). They add plenty of content on a regular basis and since the free animals are changed weekly, even the for-free-players can enjoy that content. All that AND being the best hunting simulator on the market is obviously not enough to get comprehensible reviews on steam. I´ll suggest that they should take 50 bucks for the package that´s free at the moment in order to get great reviews from satisfied consumers!

												If you are looking for a ''real'' hunting experience, this is probably the best game out there, without a doubt. This is not like Cabela's hunting games, where you massacre animals with assault rifles and machine guns, this is a realistic hunting experience. This game actually offers a real hunting experience, where you have to track down animals, and when you get your first kill or track down an animal that you have been searching for in hours, you actually feel like you have achieved something.Sadly, this game, in my opinion, fails at its F2P model. If you actually want to hunt all sorts of animals you will have to invest some money into the game, otherwise, There is only one type of animal that you can hunt. It feels more like a demo than a free to play title, this is sadly what scares a lot of people away. But if you can cope with the F2P model, and are willing to invest money into the game, this game is amazing.

												I had heard that the game was a poor excuse for a free-to-play, but I still decided to give it a try.  And, in my honest opinion, it is a really cool game.  The visuals, sounds, and atmosphere are great, it's a game that's relaxing to play, and it's cool to simply explore the areas.  But I cannot recommend it to anyone and have decided to stop playing myself because it really is the most incredibly money-grabbing game I have personally ever seen, especially for one that claims to be free-to-play.  You can't hunt almost any animals without spending money or earning a lot of the in-game currency, you can't get new weapons without spending money, you can't get get ammo without spending money or earning a large amount of the in-game currency, and you can't get almost any (if any) other equipment without spending real money.  And missions, what seem to be the main way of earning in-game currency, are incredibly limited in what you can actually do without spending money on the game.  It even claims to be multiplayer, but you can't host that to do with friends without spending money on the game either.  I wasn't even able to participate in their Halloween event without buying some form of weapon and/or ammo.  If the developers decide they actually care about their players instead of milking as much money as possible I'd gladly come back to the game, but not until then.

content:
4, 2015
												Love this game, the only reason so m any people hate it is because it says free to play and it isn't. I would urge the makers of the game to remove its free to play status and just be honest. It is limited for free to play and it's mostly a pay to play game. With that being said, I'll continue with why I love the game.It is an EXCELLENT pay to play game and literally the only online game I have subscribed to aside from World Of Warcraft when I was younger. Me, my buddy and my girlfreind spend hours at a time stalking and killing Elk with the amazing tracking system and the detailed injury system, allowing you to see exactly what organs you've hit on the animal after you collect the kill. This helps you to make a more precise and fast kill the next time, eventually leading you from shooting wildly at the animal and tracking it forever, to shooting the animal exactly where it's vital organs are, killing it in one swift killshot. This get's even better when you use weapons that are silent like bows or crossbows, enabling you to kil animals quick and silently without alerting others in the heard they are travelling with. I've taken doiwn 4 or 5 animals in one silent swipe with my buddy before, making tandem kills and picking the off animals lagging behind the rest of the heard.I also enjoy that there are many different ways to earn the in game real money currency "em$". Aside from spending your cash on it, you can also earn it by completing competitions, which with a free memebrship can be very difficult, but with just the basic package, it allows you to kill nearly all the animals (with the exception of a few that require specific equipment) and take part in most competition with at least some chance to achieve victory if you are really dedicated enough. You can also earn "em$" by completeing simple tasks such as filling out surveys, downloading apps onto your phone (tha can be immediatly removed) or registering to a website and confirming an E-mail. I've earned well ove 10,000 em$ through this process and although I have spent real money on the game, if I really wanted to, I could just keep completeing these tasks to earn whatever guns or equipment I wanted.Finally I'll talk about the dev team. With regular updates, bug fixes and new features being added to the game, it really feels like you're paying into the development of the game. New areas, new animals to hunt and just recently the addition of hunting dogs, really lets you know that the dev team is working hard to bring you new and exciting features for the game.Many people are turned off by the amount of money that can be dropped on the game, and I can see where the concern comes from, but this is one of the best hunting games I've ever played and although I hope they change their pricing model some day, I'm willing to pay for the amazing features in this game right now, given the quality of it.Edit: Also I should mention that the price of being able to hunt all animals is very low (in my opinion anyway). The first 3 month will cost you $5.66 a month and give you a pump shotgun which will allow you to hunt literallly every animal in the game. If you feel like doing missions until you can buy the single shot shotgun with the unpaid currency (Gm$) than you could pay for a 3 month membership for $3.66 a month and be able to hunt every single animal in the game. Since it gives you unlimited ammo you can hunt as much as you want during that time and it wont be a problem. Keep in mind that you can win competitions to get the paid currency, but they can be quite difficult to rank in. Also, people seem to have a problem with the amount of game hours I have in the game so I'll explain why I have so many. If you leave the initial "thehunter" browser open, steam counts you as in game and thus you get a billion hours in a week if you leave it open. I leave my browser open nearly all the time since me my buddies and my gf play so often, and so I can get the latest news they have updated the game with. So if you think it's sketchy that I have so many hours in the game, it's literallyn just because I leave the main browser open.

number of helpful: 17 of 24 people (71%) found this review helpful
content:
6, 2014
												Ok then - theHunter. It's rivalling in terms of hours played my other big favourite of the moment, DayZ, and I'd like to tell you why.Firstly I am a real life hunter and shooter, but living in the UK access to real weapons and hunting isn't always easy. So when I saw this game for free, I thought it's worth giving a go. I haven't seen another game in this niche for 10 years, so I was keen to see what it offers.I'm going to deal with the free to play issue. This game can be played for free. You can access all areas of the reserves straight away, and beautiful they are. Yes you are given two weapons for ffree - a scoped .243 and a 12 bore shotgun, but these two weapons are good for all but one species on the many reserves you can hunt on, and have limitless ammo. In terms of what you can hunt, you are restricted to one species of deer to start with but can also hunt three variants of rabbits plus pheasants for free. Additionally you will get two extra species free to hunt every week on a rotating basisYes there is downloadable content to buy - if you want to - but it's not at all necessary for the enjoyment of the game. I compare it to a well known MMO tank game; you can do it all for free if you want and earn your way to stuff in game play or you can add real money and do it quicker and funner. TheHunter's the same - it gives you the option to use real money if you really want to.Pricing if you want to use real cash? Well it's minimal. Yes there is the option to buy a membership which for me is 8 English pence a day giving me licenses for all animals on the reserves plus free reloads of ammo. In terms of £ spent to hours played, as I have bought some extras, I'm on about £40 for over 200 hours, and I can see the hours going up and the £ spent staying at about £40. Considering I was charged £1 to aprk for 30 minutes today in town, I don't find this bad value for money at all.Game play and graphics are ok - I do find it very immersive with TrackIR and Dolby 7.1 headphones. 60fps at highest graphic settings doesn't strain my middle of the road desk top PC.What makes this game a challenge is that stalking and fieldcraft are probably more important than the shooting element. This is not some sort of immersive shooting gallery. Game can be elusive, wary, spookable, and even dangerous. If all you require is a game to blast holes in things try Sniper Elite.The only downside for me is that the designers have had to make some gameplay approximations and simplifications which make the game less realistic, and less of a challenge. The most notable one for me is that the rifle trajectories are effectively flat, and range finding isn't really part of the game as your encounter ranges tend to be well under 50 metres. There's no wind effect on the shot either, so real life skills of range finding, usind hold over for range, and allowing for the wind don't appear here which is a shame.Game play summary: you will spend a lot of time walking slowly from cover to cover straining your ears and eyes for the signs of animals which you can then track and if you get it right you will eventually see them and get in a position to shoot. A critic called it a walking simulator - sounds like he was a poor hunter as stealth is the key.So thinking of trying it? Well all you have to lose is the download time to your disc. If you like the first couple of hours you'll probably decide to splash a little cash for a basic membership to give you quicker access to hunting species other than the free mule deer.I've seen a review below where someone makes out that if you want to play the game you need to buy this and buy that and the sums run into large amounts of $. It's not so. You do not need to buy every bit of kit in the game - one shotgun with its birdshot, buckshot and solid slug will let you take on every single species on the map.So that's it for me. It is a good hunting simulator. There is Gucci gear available for real £ but you can do a lot with a very little £. You can do massive amounts with no £ at all as long as you accept: a) you need to work your way up the game to earn in game currency b) you need to use the right skills to do this - play like a CoD buffoon and you'll never succeed c) that people with real £ can buy goodies if they want to without stopping the game being free to play d) that there is no 'win' in this game other than the satisfaction you get from hunting with skill

content:
r 27, 2014
												After the apocalypse, Steve and his family moved to the coast of Norway. All was good and well until the family ran out of food supplies. Steve, who had worked in an office before the apocalypse, didn't really know how to use a gun, and had never killed an animal. But his family was starving, so he decided to give it a shot. Steve found an old rifle and som bullets in the cabin where they were living, and set out to find some food.He hadn't been searching for long, when suddenly a wild boar appeared. Steve laid down, pointed the hole-y end towards the animal, and pulled the trigger.  Nothing happened.  He was shocked at first, but later realised that the gun didn't want to cooperate beacuse he DIDN'T OWN THE LICENSE TO KILL THE ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ THING. Dissappointed, Steve set out to find some other animal. After a while a Peasant appeared.  Steve pointed the gun towards it, and pulled the trigger. Nothing happened again. HE DIDN'T OWN THE LICENSE TO KILL PEASANTS. No matter how he tried, Steve couldn't find an animal that he owned the license to kil..  After a couple of days he was awfully thirsty, hungry and stressed out. That gun started to look very very compelling.He pointed it towards his head, pulled the trigger, and nothing happened. HE DIDN'T OWN THE LICENSE TO KILL HIMSELF. Instead he decided to jump of a cliff, and shortly after that his family starved to death. THE END.Seriously though, are there any animals that you're actually allowed to kill in this game? Havent found any yet, and it's annoying me to death :P

number of helpful: 23 of 36 people (64%) found this review helpful
content:
6, 2014
												PRELUDE: If you're mature and appreciate high quality games continue reading. The rating on the review is because of immature idiots who want everything for free - got nothing to do with the game. If you're a spoiled immature brat wanting more handouts to go with your welfare cheque, mark it down and ♥♥♥♥ off. Don't bother with entitlement whining in the comments, I'll just kill it...oo00oo..Now, the game.- GRAPHICS -This is gorgeous. A 6.00am start at Redfeather had me mesmerised. There are some placing issues, grass and trees above ground etc. but it's really only aesthetics and does little to detract gameplay. With my trusty 670gtx/i7/8Gb rig this game shines with only minor fan speedup when scene changing. A steady 60fps with only minor tearing (I haven't bothered changing the default yet so could probably be sorted easily enough).Very easy to look at and the animalation (now there's a word) is very attractive. Slightly robotic at times but hey, if we had 500,000 vectors to plot per animal we couldn't play without a Cray.- SOUND -There could be a little more control over some of the ambients, eg: ocean waves, as sound is a critcal and tactile sense in this game and some of it gets over the top. Rain, wind etc. is good and animal calls, while lacking in some bearing seperation, is true to form.And the guns? Wow. Crank it people. It might take 2 hours of tracking before you fire but I get great delight hearing the .308 reverb off the valley walls. My kids, avid fans all, bounce off their chair! The bang-ratchet-bang of the pump action while pheasant shooting is as sweet as.(Err.... an 11.00pm .308 shot scored me some wife-wrath so headphones people!)- GAMEPLAY -If holding shift + W is your only way to get somewhere this is NOT your thing. If the destination is more important than the journey or you're expecting a gluttony of "shootables", DO NOT BUY.This requires patience and lots of it, much of it is tedium. This is hunting. You are a hunter. Stealth. Cover. Shadows. Crouching. Camoflauge. Downwind. ALL of this comes into play.  I've even suggested on the forums that you need to move like YOU are the hunted for best results. Animals, particularly those munched on by predators have an uncanny sense of smell and hearing. And it IS fascinating to watch animals through a scope pausing, sniffing and treading lightly. "Wary skittishness" has been modelled beautifully and really adds to the sense of the hunters plight... Let's face it, we're blundering lunkheads in natures true arena and you'll pay the price for it.-Shooting. In RL, I have probably loosed close to 10,000 rounds. Mostly night shooting for foxes and roos. As a staunch user of the .243 in that era I took great delight in how well this acts, sounds and plays like a .243 ingame. I can "feel" the shoulder kick and smell the powder. (I know, it's psychosomatic but you get what I'm saying....)Scope tracking is well mimiced and looking downrange for a headshot @ 150m is frustratingly difficult. Zoom capabilities are also true-to-form in that higher zoom will produce greater scope movement. Nice work in this department. Note that there are many scopes, sizes and types, many aimed (yck yck) at quality shooting and range judgement.- The shotty is divine albeit a rather blunt instrument. - The .30 is popular and goes off like a firecracker on steroids.- The Anshutz .308 -a spend money on it- gun has just entered my inventory and is a darling to use. I linked it up with a 9x50 and I'm REALLY loving this outfit.I've made mention on the forums that I'm concerned that there is no score rewards based on target range despite the obvious (monetary) push to high-quality equipment. In my view this is wrong, both ingame and economically. My weapons and equipment need to be valuable to me but there is no reason to use anything other than a 12 gauge with the right ammo for the kill. Why charge up to $15 RL money for a gun and scope that counts towards.... nothing?-Animal TrackingI like the way this has been done. It's very difficult to mimic the senses from a 3D enviroment in a 2D rectangle and yet this gives a sense of tracking success with target sighting as the eventual reward. The kill itself does become secondary on the harder to track species and I've once or twice found myself shooting only a photo and simply walking away. Seriously.-CompetitionsGood fun and ultimately (at least for me) is the reason I play. Nope, I haven't won any as I write but I've got close. The planning and dedication required to win a trophy is high level stuff and really needs to be worked at. I'm loving them. Soon.......- GENERAL -In the interests of brevity I'm going to mention the words achievements (LOTS of them), missions, multiplayer, XP building all in the one sentence. The reasons will be quite obvious. You gotta pay to play, not a real lot, and it's worth every cent.- UI - In a sentence on the launcher windows. Messy. Clunky. Confusing. EW. Get someone on this. Rule of thumb, evaluate your UI on your grandmothers. If they're confused it's bad OK?  Even ingame I find some "habit formed clicking" breaks on some changes to equipment. ..oo00oo..- SUMMARY -CONSTedious at times with all that walking.Could ultimately cost quite a bit.UI.Scoring is errr.... pointless. (pun intended)As an Aussie, I find it filled with Americanised hunting claptrap and hyperbole. Less Greenpeace and more hunting is needed, it's a GAME :)PROSAwesome sound/graphics on good/high-end systems.Great immersion and true-to-life animals and in particular their behaviour.Good choice of weaponry and associated peripheral match-ups.Provides a very real sense of hunting.If you're an RL hunter but can't get out enough. GET THIS. No question.9/10 (amended score and review*)gg*Amended review to reflect continued use. 1000+ hours now and still immersed. Heavily. :)

content:
ber 27, 2016
												Okay, where do I start with this?? I am going to start out saying that this will be my first lengthy review about any game in my Library. Why?? Because I feel like this game is NOT getting fair feedback looking at the overall reviews. Even when you read the Posotive Reviews of this game, NO ONE sheds light into what this game is AND why they rated it a Positive. And I hope that this review will ease your mind into actually giving this game a try, and finding out for yourself that the reviews either consist of .....1. People who does not have a job as of yet, want to play the best hunting game around, but can not afford this.2. Trolls just hating on the game because of the Free to Play aspect of this game and NOT the overall game itself3. People that has a COMPLETE wrong mindset of the Pay to Play factor and NEVER even tried to pay to play the gameand that I will go into bigger detail about those factors and why the review score is Mostly Negative because of those 3 points. In the process, I will also clarify a few things for anyone reading this review, and I hope you stick around to read it all. I promise it will be worth while, and that it will change your mind towards things to actually give this game a shot. Because, I was just like you (The Reader) at the start of it all, and also just like you (The Reader) my reaction to this game, the reviews and the Pay to Play factor just drove me away from this game COMPLETELY. When in the end, all that was needed to enjoy this game to full, was $49.99. How is that for Pay to Play??Okay, now for the actuall review.I will go as far as to say that this is the best hunting sim I have ever played, even though I was sceptical at the start because of the whole Pay to Play aspect of the game. At the time I HATED this game because it was Free to Play, but I cant even shoot anything in the game, because everytime I want to shoot, it tells me I need a license for this and license for that. I just got mad, and at the moment I felt like this game is the biggest pile of crap I have EVER played. Who even plays a crap game like this AND pours money into it?? What is this, another World of Warcraft??Till one day, I just felt like wasting money, and decided to waste money onto this game, because why not?? I went to the store page of this game's Launcher, and I went to purchase a Membership. Looking at the options I had, I decided to go with the Trailrunner Subscription ($49.99), which gives me a 12 month (Year) Membership to shoot what I want, where I want AND to ease me into the game, I got 9 extra Weapons to start off my game AND 35 other items to accompany me. Ranging from scopes for my 9 Weapons, Cammo, Lures, Backpack and much more usefull items. Eager to start out the game AND still keeping in mind that there is still MUCH MORE to purchase in the game store than what I got with my Subscription, I started a new game, and made due with what I had for the time being. The game started up and the hunt was on. With my lure at hand and my trusty .300 (Gotten from Trailrunner Subscription) I was determine to shoot some Deer.I set out with my trusty HunterMate, and I started learning the game and what goes for what. My first encounter was a Turkey. I went to the location of the Turkey call, and saw the tracks. My HunterMate told me in which direction the Turkey has fled, and I just follow along the path. The path led me through the Forest and Swampland areas, and I was soon greated with a Deer Grunt Call in the distance. It was at that moment I paused in my tracks. I took a crouching position, I got my Lure ready, and I called the Deer in. Sitting in the bush, looking left and right past the trees, through the bushes I am trying to find the Deer AND be as quite and low profile as I can get .... at the same time worrying about a stupid Turkey ....I saw the Deer peeking he's head over the scrubs infront of me, I bring up my .300 to scope .... I line up my shot and I just let it go. The Deer fell on the spot and I jumped with joy. I went to collect the Deer and I was happy with what I got. I went back to the tracks of the Turkey, and continued my journey.Its been a year later, and what was once a piece of crap game to waste money on, is now the best game I ever wasted money on. Funny how that works right?? Its also been a year later, and I only spend $49.99 on this game since then. Yes, you read that right. After one whole year, the Trailrunner Subscription for $49.99 was AND is all you need to enjoy this game to the fullest. I now renewed my Subscription for another year which is now $34.99. I used the other $15 and I bought myself more Lures to use on for the other animals, and I still only use my weapons and equipment I got from my Trailrunner pack. NEVER bought anything extra than what I got for spending $49.99 on this game.If you have sticked with me up until now in my review, I am sure you are now more convinced to actually try this game out INSTEAD of just looking at the Pay to Play factor and relying on the Review System of Steam.In general, all you EVER need to play this game is the Trailrunner Subscription. NOTHING more and NOTHING less. The other items you can purchase is just for better convinience and a better overall gameplay to make your life easier. In truth, the Weapons and Items you get in the Trailrunner Subsciption is MORE than enough to play this game to fullest of experience.Pros.1. Great Gameplay2. Great Hunting Sim3. A lot of Game Reserves to choose from4. Each Game Reserve has its own Game and Hunting tactics to adapt5. Overall very good hunting experience6. New Game Reserves was added (with Game) and is still being added (with Game)7. The game offers a level up system for each Weapon and Animal the more you use your Weapon and Track an Animal8. The game offers multiplayer where you can hunt with your friendsCons.1. Game engine is a bit out dated2. Devs does not seem to listen to its already small community to improve on overall user experience3. The controlls are kind of clunky and stiff, but you get use to itPutting it all together to sum it up. Purchase the Trailrunner Subscription ($49.99) and try this game out for yourself. Do NOT purchase the other subscriptions as you will not enjoy the game to the fullest, and they dont offer you as much gain as the Trailrunner Subscription does. Thats all you will EVER spend on this game in your life, and as you play the game, you will soon relise that you gave the game a unnecessary hard time BECAUSE of the overall Steam Review AND the fact that it is Pay to Play.Thank you for sticking with me the whole time through my review, if I helped you out, dont forget to click "YES" on "Was this review helpfull". And put your own positive review on this page.

												Graphics, animals and surroundings are beautiful, but this game is not really free to play.  Here is how my game experience went. This game is a nice hunting simulator, but falls short when it comes to f2p variety of huntable animals.

content:

												I really wanted to recommend this since this the first actual hunting game that I have played that had fantastic graphics and well mechanics and variety of great looking maps. 4, 2016
												DO NOT BELIEVE ALL THE NEGATIVE REVIEWS...THIS IS A GREAT HUNTING GAME!Q. Is it TOTALLY FREE to Play?A. Yes & No. This game has enough to play for free if, (A) you are just a casual hunter playing now and again,    (B) you don't mind only hunting 5 types of anaimals (Whitetail Deer, Cottontail & European Rabbits, Snowshoe Hare, Pheasant),    (C) you play to earn gm$ (in game money) by doing missions, then spend that on other game licenses.Q. Do I HAVE TO SPEND A LOT of Real Money to play?A. No not at all. If you want to hunt all the animals you can get a subscription that only cost $3.33 a month (less if you get a longer sub)   If you want to own a lot of weapons, clothing, hunting dog, etc. to customise your character you'll have to spend some real money to get em$ (the in game money that you buy with real money) but how much is up to you.   *If you buy one of the "DLC" those are the subscriptions (3, 6 & 12 month) with bonus items, they cost slightly more then normal subscriptions, BUT you only by those once for the bonus items then resub at normal rate. The bonus items are worth the extra as it will save you money over buying them separately.As a FREE Player you can hunt the 5 animals I mentioned above, you can track and spot any animal in the game. You start with 2 free weapons (.243 Bolt Action Rifle and the Single Shot Shotgun).You can hunt on anywhere on the map (some areas will have nothing to shoot for free players).You can hunt with you friends in multiplayer...No You Can Not Shoot Your Friends No Matter How Much You Would Like To!Q. Can you walk for long periods of time and not spot anything? A. Yes, just like in real life you can hunt for long periods without spotting anything, you'll find lots of tracks to follow...   Also you will want to walk not run, this isn't CoD. Take your time walk crouched, listen for movement around you, just like you would have to do if you where really hunting.If you like hunting games give it a try...it's got a great community, nice graphics, good hunting and it's somewhat Free!

												edited august 2016after 2 years playing that game, i decided to turn my 1st positive review into a negative one. i'll try to explain why here. i used to play that game a lot but i discovered another nice game called Cabela big game hunting pro hunts 2014. i recommend Cabela BGH instead of TheHunter. here's why- TheHunter is not a game you own, it's a membership. You spend hundreds of euros in equipment, but the game doesn't belong to you. If you stop your membership, or the devs stop the game tomorrow, you loose everything. this is an unpleasant feeling-TheHunter is a game full of bugs. the devs release stuff every week so the bugs stack, and right now it has reached a point of you can't play a single session without facing a bug-TheHunter is an expensive game. the membership doesn't cost a lot itself, but the most simple rifle/equipment will cost you 5 euros. buy 5 rifles, 3 tripods, 3 treestands, 5 tents, and 3 bows, do a simple maths (5x5)+(3x5)+(3x5)+(5x5)+(3x5)=80+membership (40)=120 euros, and i didn't count clothes, dogs etc ..- if you hunted irl, animals calling system in TH may be very problematic. in TH animals call all the time. and they do it so you can hear them. been hunting years irl, and over that whole period i heard only a fox once at dusk- personnally i have a real luminosity problem here. the environments are dark. and you can't use sweetfx, because the publisher policy toward modding is 0 tolerance. i understand they don't want modding because of their commercial strategy. but they don't allow the use of reshade.me because they say it would be problematic for the competitions. yeah, that's true that hunting has always been a competition affair ...-Cabela will cost you 5-20 euros depending if you get it on a sale, but it's a one time purchase-in Cabela animals have better behaviors, they turn into your direction, and look at you when you approach. pigs eat etc-animals are beautiful in Cabela-bullet time is really fun, especially with the bowsTheHunter is free to play, you can hunt whitetail for free, and see by yourself. but before buying a pack have a  look at Cabela's pigs

content:
2, 2014
												I am a long time player and will try to make this review informative and realistic.*** GameplayI tried this game and liked it so much that I purchased a one-year membership after a few days. The relaxed and realistic atmosphere is likely one of the biggest sellers for the game. You basically roam the woods looking for animals, or clues that can lead you to them. There are a lot more animals in the game than what you would see in real life. Also the animals are less shy than in nature, so that you will find plenty of them even in a short hunting session. You will discover traces on the ground or hear animals call somewhere in the distance. Once an animal is tracked down, you may opt for a kill or move on. Tracking gets easier the more you play. With the increasing number of tracks that you pick up, your skill level rises and tracking becomes easier. It also happens a lot that you see single animals or a group of them roaming around as you walk through the reserves. This game is not for someone trying to get satisfaction in a lot of animal shooting in a short time. *** MembershipsAll players start as "guest" and receives a free rifle and life-long free ammunition for this gun and some basic equipment. A membership is a time-limited license that will unlock all animals, free ammunition for all weapons, and also the ability to host multiplayer parties. A permanent license is not available.*** Hunting GroundsThe reserves in the western part of this world resemble of American continent-based areas, the eastern part holds areas that you could easily find in Europe. Currently seven reserves are available. Each has its own charm and of course its animal species. At the beginning of every hunt you select a reserve. You can start from a permanent lodge or from a tent that you have placed in the reserve before. The maps are very big and if needed there is a fast travelling system.*** AnimalsAt this point the game features 18 species. Some of them can attack the player. Many can be lured with callers, scents or decoys. Then there are baiting stations that will bring the animals to a certain location. Most bird species are only scored if shot in the air, which is always a fun challenge. For many species unusual fur variations can be found, some of which are truly rare. Shooting such a rare animal is just as special as a trophy buck. Shooting animals in theHunter quite demanding. The animals have bones and organs, and every shot should be thought through before the trigger is pulled. Hitting vital organs will lead to death, bad shots can result in a follow-up search.*** WeaponsA host of rifles is available, all of which can be equipped with scopes for longer shots. Using the open sights can be just as much fun though. Depending on the knock-down capabilities of these guns they are allowed to be used for larger or smaller game. There is also a selection of handguns, some with plenty of power to even kill a moose. Shotguns can be used with three types of ammunition, which makes them all-around weapons for all animals. Shooting guns makes all animals in the area flee. Bows can be used as silent killers and will not alarm other animals unless they are really close.*** EquipmentThere is equipment that can be permanently placed in the reserves. Tents let you to start a hunt where ever you placed them before, and they give you access to your entire inventory just like a lodge. There are treestands that can be mounted to trees for a better overview of the area. Ground and waterfowl blinds protect you on the ground from being seen, and a tripod stand provides some elevation for easier animal spotting. *** In-game MoneyAll game items are paid with the in-game currency em$. It can be purchased with real money, won in competitions, or earned by completing third-party offers. Also there are gm$ that can be earned by completing missions, allowing to buy consumables. Non-consumable items belong to the player permanently, even if a membership expires. *** MissionsCurrently there are a total of 245 missions available. Most mission packs start rather easy and become increasingly more difficult. You will end up shooting pheasants or geese in air with bows, or try to make a moose attack you for an adrenaline kill.*** Competitions & LeaderboardsCompetitions are run around the clock for all animals. Players from around the world sign up and compete against each other. The top players receive a trophy which appears on the player's profile. In addition em$ can be earned. All animals of all players are compared during every season and represented on leaderboards. The best players will make their way into the Hall of Fame. *** MultiplayerMultiplayer parties are client-based, there are no MP servers. In the game it is possible to chat with others. Players can hunt as team or on their own. It is advisable that people from the same geographical regions connect for such games, or there can be lagging.*** Things I don't like- The website's style is not "outdoor-like". Also the font size and the line spacing are too large. There is a lot of scrolling to be done when going through statistics or the store.- The large antlers of the Red Deer are completely unrealistic. The red deer in the game does not look like the real one, and that is a real pity for me, being European.- Some animals have too large eyes and thus look like large baby animals. The most obvious ones are the Brown Bear and the Roe Deer.- It is not possible to jump or climb over the smallest obstacles and you have to circumvent them.  Sometimes it would be handy to climb a rock and gain a bit better overview, but many rocks cannot be climbed.*** ConclusionThe game is constantly being enhanced with new content. It remains one of the best games I have ever played, and certainly played for the longest time. Playing long nights is not tiring even if it gets really busy around you at times. It is unique with its  lively environment and ambient sounds, but can be just as much challenging when trying to pin down the trophy animal. There is a great random factor and unpredictability, which I think among many other things is the greatest achievement of the developers. I keep playing because every game session can be so much different to the former, and so the game just never gets old.

content:
1, 2014
												Hi everyone! I hope you're all doing well today. So I gave this "f2p" a try and found it's simply "f2t" which means it isn't really free to play at all. It's free-2-try. The pricing is ridiculous. If I'm going to spend this kind of money, I'll be doing some real hunting. If you have tons of money and think you might give this a try anyway, I suppose it might be fun practice for some folks. Anyway, let me tell you how my hour in the game went, and you can judge for yourself if you want to try.I play on three monitor Nvidia Surround. Some games have built in limitations to make it fair, but I don't think that's the case with this game. The resolutions given in the options appear to support my setup, so I made the switch and bam! I get what looks like a normal widescreen view squashed flat and stretched across three monitors. Needless to say, I don't think the game looks very good that way. So I see a cabin and decide to walk up to it, but can't get up on the porch even though it looks like I should be able to step up. Maybe the front of the porch looks lower to me because of the stretching effect, so I walk around to the steps on the side and get up on the porch... only to find I can't open the door anyway--or at least I couldn't figure out how. So I look around and see a shooting range. I head over, pick a spot, lay down, and cannot clearly see all targets because they are obscured partly by the targets in front of them. I don't feel like creeping over to another spot because this one is clearly marked as viable and the movement mechanics are so slow and clunky, so I do some practice shooting with the one free weapon you start with by default. Wow! My persona must be a complete jitterbug because I can't seem to hold the weapon even moderately still. I open options and look for a key to let me either empy my lungs or hold my breath, find it, and... heh... not much help at all. After practice, I get up and just start wandering around the woods. I see a lot of bugs and a few birds. The sounds are great, and I think I might like this game for meditation if the view wasn't squashed flat and looking so completely odd. I do glimpse one deer off in the distance, but if I'm supposed to be able to track it I'll never know because I can't seem to find the spot where I spotted it. So I wander. And wander. I find a nice peaceful spot and sit down. And I wait. And I wait. And then I leave.If they fix the resolution, I might come back and try my luck again. If walking around and waiting seem like a good game to you, give it a try. I know this is supposed to be realistic hunting, and I'm okay with that. Really I am. But when the view is squashy, the shooting mechanics are clunky, and the movement is so darn slow and irritatingly stupid, it gets tedious to say the least. If I could at least enjoy the scenery, it might not have been such a terrible experience for me. As it is, I can't even do that. I read that if you keep practicing, your ability to hold the weapon still gets better, but I'm not sure the rest of my experience rates a keep-trying approach.No, I can't recommend this game. You might try it and like it, but for me, it just doesn't work. I'd rather be out in the real woods hunting real animals for practice. At least then, if I see a porch I want to hop up on, I can do that without having to creep slowly around to the steps on the side. Talk about silly.

content:
9, 2014
												Where do I begin? If this game had a "you buy it, you get everything, all guns/licenses/reserves/etc for a flat $50.00" (which is a new release AAA price), I probably would've done it. But the nickle-and-diming ridiculousness of their membership plans is something I won't accept. Even most MMORPG's have a hard time maintaining a monthly subscription, yet theHunter thinks that people will keep doling out the money to retain to their guns/licenses/access to certain parts of the game.What if I don't want to play for the full 3 months? It makes the customer feel like they're flushing money down the drain. I'd rather hand over a big chunk up front, get my entire game, and be able to pick it up when I feel like it. Not, oh 5 months down the road I think about trying it again, and they want even more money.The real trick is that if they do sucker you into paying for a membership, at the end of that time, you suddenly realize... I'm going to lose all my access, but I've got all this progress I want to keep working on, I don't want to lose it and should pay more to keep going! That's how they'll hook you and keep the cash flowing in endlessly, as opposed to simply letting people buy the full game normally and be done with it.As to the actual gameplay... The animals are few and far between, and most of the time when you find a track, it's frequently not going to be the kind you're allowed to hunt. Which is pretty much only mule deer, and you have one gun. So every time annoying pheasants or whitetail deer pops up on the Huntermate tracking device, you get reminded to either fork over the money or you're blocked from certain content. It's irritating.The game world itself is gorgeous, and the tracking system is uniquely detailed -- but that's not nearly enough to make me overlook the above issues. I would be a customer, if it weren't for their greedy scheme.The other hysterical part is that they actually asked their fans to leave positive reviews, because they think all the bad reviews "create a distorted picture of the community's feelings." How about you stop trying to cover up people's genuine reactions to your greediness? The majority are voicing their complaints that this is a bad business model.

content:
2016
												I'll make this quick,This game is a ton of fun espically if you're a hunter in real life, there's a lot of negative comments here too about how this game isn't free and it's posing as one (last I checked).  It is free indeed, you can hunt three or four animals as a guest and those animals are as followed.WhitetailCottontail rabbitPheasant.There's also special events that go on that allows you to hunt certain animals for a certain ammount of time for free, however. If you wish to invest in the game, it's actually a fair deal and they're not asking for a a lot either. 500 ems is worth 4.99 USD and 3 months of memberhip is around 10$ USD, there's obviously other options but those are the two cheapest and it's quite fair if you ask me.Overall, I really enjoy this game, it's a lot of fun getting to hunt the animals in the map locations, plus it's really good for time consumption as well. After all, I play this game when I do my homework while sitting in a tree stand or hunting tower lol.Either way to sum things up, don't judge this game by the negative reviews until you actually tried it yourself, you may or may not like it and this is as close as hunting I can get when the season for whitetail irl isn't opened.So overall, if you're a fellow real life hunter as myself here, you'll enjoy the game!

ry 15, 2015
												OK...heres the real story. YES...you need a membership to hunt all animals, but you can try the game for free  and hunt muledeer, with a rifle they give you for free. If you like the game then fine, you can order a 3,6 or yearly memberships, and its fairely cheep. The bigger the memberhsip you order the more free stuff you get. I ordered a 6 month membership and got everything I think I'd need to play forever, in guns anyways. If you have to collect everythign ingame yes it gets expensive but why do it? A shotgun can hunt anything...ANYTHING IN GAME ...because it has 3 kinds of ammo.there are fancy guns with ingraving for people who need those, but never for free..doh....and several types of bows and arrows and sights scopes, etc and on and on...but you don't need all that. For less than the cost of lottery tickets you can play all year long, and hunt every animal you ever wanted in  great detailed forests and on cold snowly mountains. No...its not all free, but trying it out is, so try it or leave it, no problem...but its a good game, just not what many people hoped for.

												Alright Guys, I Have About 570 hours in this game so i guess its time for a review. So As You All See it says its a free to play, it actually is though. But heres the catch, that "free" word can be quite tricky. you see when you start playing the game, you get all pumped "Like oh boy im gonna kill everything" well your wrong because you're basically gonna be playing a demo, you get a few animals to shoot as long with 2 animals you can hunt that rotate through out every week. you can't create your own multiplayer server but you can join others. The Game will always make you feel like you have to buy more and more and sometimes you give in, but if you dont want to spend money thats fine but before you go all "oh i hate this game, free to play my ♥♥♥" why dont you just give it a shot and spend atleast a few hours (2-3) trying to find a male whitetail or something, it also helps to have a friend there with you that knows this game better, this game almost sucks without a friend when you first start playing, theres a hunting forums for this game and this community loves to help out new players. My Point is this game isnt that bad if you just give it a shot.

content:
4, 2016
												99% of the reviews on the hunter are negative because people complain about how it is marketed as a "free to play" game. If you want to play the game properly you will have to spend a bit of money. But after you get a membership the game becomes sooooooo much better. You need to be patient to play the hunter and by the looks of the other reviews, not many people on steam are. Make sure you play the tutorials or you will have no idea what you are doing and maybe watch a youtube video or two (e.g. theHunter Beginner's Guide 2016 by HooCairsTheHunter). If you are a new guest I recommend sticking to the towers and calling the deer to you, as they can see, smell and hear you alot better with guest clothes on. There is free shotgun in the store which I dont think many guests know about, so get the shotgun and go clay pigeon shooting (don't worry about wasting ammo because it is unlimited in the vacinity of a range or lodge) or go pheasant hunting and if you like it, buy the membership. I also recommend going to thehunter on wikia as it gives you tonnes of information on reserves and where you can specifically find the animals.

												Firstly I'll just say this is the best hunting game I have played and by simply buying the $15 subscription and spending another $5 on EM to buy yourself a 300 magnum you can do basically everything in the game. free to play is very limited but still fun. Its a scam. I payed for access to software in one deal to try to get a good rate on EM currency which never arived and after speaking with their support staff found out that that company claims no affiliation with either the advertising company or with TheHunter so in the end lesson learned.Granted a small few of the "download and open this app" ones worked for a small amount on EM but nothing else did. TheHunter are advertising this service of earning EM inside there own game from and ingame window and should be held responsable for the clear violation of the fair traiding act in false advertising.

number of helpful: 9 of 13 people (69%) found this review helpful
content:
13, 2014
												Hello All HuntersI been playing this game before it even came to steam. I been on it for almost 3 years I believe. I really enjoy this game since this is the closest I can come to being a hunter without buying a hunting license, a gun and ammo, and a lease. I find the graphics to be pretty detailed and all the ambient sound makes it feel like I'm actually in the wild. As a F2P (a term everyone hates) shooter, its fun and relaxing at the same time. The game isn't perfect by no means with some AI bugs, pop ups, limited draw distance, and other hic-ups. But everyone grips about hunting only mule deer and having 1 rifle and deer calls. You have to buy a license to hunt other animals in the game that roam around in the same world. They grip about license expiring after certain set times. People forget that this is cheaper than going out and buying real life guns, ammo, leases, and a hunting license thats good for 1 year. Enough of my short rant. Only thing I don't like about the game is that to get em$, you have to ether buy it or do third party surveys, apps, videos, or other stuff they want you to do for the em$. The missions are a nice touch but only reward you with gm$ which you use to buy different ammo. And to buy extra guns, stands, and other calls you'll need em$ which is hard to come by. Other then those grips the game is a pretty run and relaxing hunting trip thats so much better than a Cabela's hunting game any day.Multiplayer - Basicly if you are a guest (F2P) you can't host any multiplayer game but you can join but due to the restriction of the guest, you can only hunt on Logger's Point. But members can host any game and set any restriction on who can join.
