content:
3, 2014
Addictive Gaming ExperienceAbout Me:  I only show to have a few hours into the game since it recently released to Steam, but have played since release & have over 1500 total played hours over the years.  I enjoy both Hunting & Gaming, so finding & playing the best hunting game comes natural to me.TheHunter:  First things first...this is not a shoot-em'-up game where you sprint through the woods guns-a-blazin'.  You will often be crouching through the woods or sitting in a stand, if that's your preference.  Some will see this game style as a bit slow or even boring at times, especially if they're used to playing a FPS.  That being said, theHunter is a good compromise between Hunting Simulation & video game.  StrengthsVariety:  There are currently 18 different species that you can hunt in theHunter, and that number continues to grow as they add new content.  There are the small deer species (roe, blacktail, whitetail, mule deer), larger deer species (roosevelt elk, moose, red deer), waterfowl (mallards & Canadian geese), canines (fox & coyote), hogs (wild boar & feral hogs), bear (black & brown), birds (pheasant & turkey), and small game (rabbits).  There are also 7 different maps for you to hunt these animals, containing anywhere from 4 to 6 different species in each map.  You also have access to 32 different weapons with which to choose from, which allows you to hunt with a variety of rifles, pistols, primitive bows, compound bows, shotguns, a flintlock muzzleloader, or even an air rifle, each with different scopes for you to use.  Further adding to the variety offered in theHunter are the different types of camo & large equipment, such as treestands, blinds, feeders, bear bait barrels, etc. Replayability:    When you start a new game in theHunter, the animals are randomly generated on the map.  This only happens once, which is right when the game starts.  There are no “respawns” as you harvest animals throughout the course of your game.  Nobody knows exactly how this works, but suffice to say that you have close to an equal number of each species on the map that you selected.  There will always be animals that are trophy worthy, and it is up to you to use your skill & patience to find them.  Along with the trophy animals are rare variations of almost every species offered.  This gives you a real sense of accomplishment when you find an albino bull elk, that trophy piebald whitetail, or the rarest of rare bears.  All of the deer species use a system called TruRacs that generates the antlers that you see in-game, and it is different every time.  All of these things, combined with the variety above, give this game a great amount of addictive replayability.  In one hunt, you might be shooting for a red deer muzzleloading competition in Hirschfelden wearing the trapper outfit & in the next you might be hunting mallard ducks in the swamps of the Rougarou Bayou online with your friends.  Even if you start in the same location & hunt the same species repeatedly, no two animals you kill will be identical & no two hunts will be the same.Adding to the replayability in theHunter are Competitions, Missions, Achievements, & Skills.  There is at least one Competition available every day for each species, most often lasting a day or two each.  There are also 250 different Missions available.  These are optional, but now earn you a currency called gm$, which can be spent on some consumable items, such as scent eliminator spray.  You can also increase your Hunter score by earning Achievements, which are mostly earned through killing x number of species or x number of kills with each weapon.  You also increase your skills along the way, making you better at tracking & spotting game.  An expert tracker can tell the sex of the animal, along with good estimates of the track’s age & the weight of the animal, while an expert spotter can give you a really good estimate of the animal’s score.Developer/Community:  This is easily the best gaming community that I have ever had the pleasure of playing & communicating with.  The developers are actively involved in the Forums, and allow the community to make suggestions for future content.  They send out surveys regularly & then deliver the content that the community wants.  The community also hosts their own competitions that pay out significantly more than the official ones.  Special Events:  theHunter throws out some pretty cool special events for certain holidays.  Sometimes, it’s just a special item (see Xmas beanie or St Patty’s Day hat) but sometimes it can be weeks’ long competitions that award guns or special trophies that are only awarded during that time.Graphics:  All in all, the game is absolutely beautiful, with nice water & weather effects.  Inside 200m the game is breathtaking.  The graphics do show their weakness if you’re zooming in with binoculars or a scope beyond 250m or so.  That is an engine issue, which I will talk about below.Weaknesses:Dated Game Engine:  The biggest weakness in theHunter is it’s dated game engine.  Specifically, the draw range of animals & most objects is limited to somewhere around 250m.  While the game boasts realistic ballistics & has beautiful scenery, that immersion is broken when you reach the summit of a mountain in Hammerfel and can’t spot animals on the opposite mountain.  You see, due to the limited nature of the engine, the game doesn’t draw those animals.  They exist, but you can’t see them until they come inside that 250m range.  Cost:  I personally don’t agree with this being a weakness, but I’ve been around theHunter long enough to know that most do view this as an area of concern.  First, let me say that the “Free to Play” is extremely limiting, and it should be.  I wish they wouldn’t even market it this way, as it gives people the wrong impression from the outset.  The bottom line is the game offers you a ton of content, much of which is not necessary, but costs money.  You can hunt every species in the game with the basic single shot shotgun that can be purchased with your gm$ earned through Missions, you can spend a little extra for gold engraved shotguns & rifles, or you can land somewhere in between.  Purchasing the Trailrunner membership is easily the best bet for the new player, giving you all you need to hunt every species on every map for a year for $43.99, and is my advice for anybody that is just starting out.  If you still want to play after that year has expired, then in my opinion, it’s well worth the money to extend your membership.OVERALL:theHunter is an addictive blend of hunting simulation & gaming, offering high replayability through randomly generated animals, enormous maps, variety in hunting methods & species.  You always have a carrot to chase, whether it’s finding that next trophy animal, looking for rare variations, trying to win competitions, reach the leaderboards & hall of fame, or completing achievements, missions, and increasing your skills.  If you can afford the Trailrunner ($43.99) membership and don’t mind the slower playstyle of a hunting simulation, then I wouldn’t hesitate to pick this game up.

												It is best to think of TheHunter as a full-priced game in which you have to invest atleast 50 euro's: a pathfinder-membership for half a year and an additional twenty euro's for buying some necessary gear which will make hunting a lot easier. This investment is only worth it, if you enjoy a slow-paced realistic hunting game with hours of walking around, tracking and preparing. That is not to say that it will take you hours to make your first kill. With some due dilligence, a quarter of an hour is enough to encounter a deer that walks past your sights and gives you the opportunity to collect your first trophy. And that's what makes this game not only good, but at times even masterful. The satisfaction of landing a kill is immense if you spent a lot of work preparing for the perfect shot. If all this appeals to you, TheHunter is a great game. It is beautiful, immersive, dense, packed with wildlife and loads of equipment and weapons to explore; that is, provided you pay for them...

content:
er 10, 2015
												I recommend The Hunter for anyone that has ever wondered how hunting really is. It's a free game that allows people to hunt Whitetail Deer, pheasant, and all types of rabbits. The graphics and realism of the animal's detection system is as realistic as hunting can be. Hunting is a game of patience & stealth and always has been - elements that are accurately instilled into this game. Don't anticipate collateral noscope headshots playing this.~Pros~-Amazing Graphics & incredible terrain with 60-80 fps-Diverse hunting terrains from swamps to dense forests to the arctic circle-Great AI and animations that replicates animal's mannerisms in real life-Very realistic ambient sound effects that are unique to each map-Surround sound footsteps, calls, & noises help narrow down your prey's location-Play with friends (for free!)-9 of 10 maps have something huntable for free accounts-Realistic Ballistics-Licenses to hunt other animals can be acquired from completing missions~Cons~-(Biggest)You need to pay a monthly subscription for licenses to hunt any other type of animal -No lump sum payment to just buy the game for all of its content - you must pay monthly.I have only played the free version of this game and still enjoy it everytime. It is a very relaxing experience that grows in intensity once you're stalking your prey. Once you get your first kill, you'll want to come back for more.Give it a try, after all, it is free!---------------------------------------------------UPDATE------------------------------------------Recently purchased the 12 month Trailrunner subscription ($50) and I could not be happier! They give you 8 guns & an awesome bow, excellent camo clothing, callers, 3 deployable towers, a tree stand, wind indicator, a tent along with licenses to hunt every animal & host your own server.I absolutely love the stealth aspect that comes with stalking your prey. Using the bow is even more challenging since you need to get very close to your animal to get the best shot. Never thought I'd enjoy the bow better than guns, but when you can silently take out a flock of turkeys/deer/elk etc. it is very fun.I'll continue to revise this review as time goes on.

content:
, 2014
												So here we are again, out in the wilderness, days gone by and your hard, throbbing member has yet to be planted into some raw, juicy rear.You sit out in your scrawny little watch tower when suddenly--Bluargh!That's it, all you've been waiting for, that one handsome and musculant call from the woods.You take out your Deer Homo Caller™ and let out one equally as homoerotic call, hoping that it'll react to it. You patiently wait out those painstaking minutes which feel like hours.You look through your binoculars and you see something, something in the bush, that isn't quite right.It's the antlers, those big, pointy and majestic antlers, piercing through the foilage, Your nerves are going haywire, your breathing is out of control, but you manage to keep your binoculars steady, as you focus on the beast.It breaks through the foilage, there is is, muscular, sweaty and musky stag just waiting to be plugged.You stow your binoculars away as you approach the galiant beast, every step you take towards it makes your heart beat faster and faster, you can see it, you can smell it, you can feel it.And there it is, right in front of you, just a stone toss away, you're ready, you've prepared your whole life for this, your senses are going through the roof.You reach into your pants, unbuckle the strap, whop out your throbbing and well-greased 'gun'.You clear your mind, slow down your breathing, and take aim.BANG!Everything quiets down, there you are, right on top of it, you stroke your hand over the fur and gently carass the antlers.After filling it up with your munition, and just as you're about to pull out, a mysterious man walks out of the woods and looks you straight in the eyes."It has come to my attention that you've been dropping Whitetail Deer with unpermitted ammo."To hell with you, Doc.

												My friend and I one night were looking for something to play together and goof off in. that's when I stumbled across this game. That is when IT happened my friend scoped up on a buck and was told that he couldn't actually HUNT it (in a game called "The Hunter") unless he payed atleast $10.  WHAT THE ♥♥♥♥ GAME. This game is not free to play. this game is free to look at. free to walk around in by yourself. free to pretend to enjoy. but this game costs atleast 10 dollars to play. content:
27, 2016
												There has been a lot of nonsense written about the Hunter so hopefully I@ll try and clear up what causes the negatives in this review.First off playing for free, I played for free for a couple of weeks, 5 species to hunt and access to all reserves (each of which is absolutely stunning). It's not so so much free to play as it is a demo tbh but a good enough demo to get me hooked.Costs involved are pretty minimal. With a memberships (about £3 or £4) a month you are allowed to hunt any animal and between the free rifle and free shotgun you have the capability to kill anything in the game except Bison which would require buying a more powerful weapon.A lot of the negative reviews are all moaning about licences but hey lets face facts here if these guys can't afford  less than a pound per week for membership then they have bigger things to worry about than computer games tbh.On to the actual game, Pros+Great feeling of being out in the wild and each reserve is styled on real world hunting locations,+Animal behaviour is well modelled+loads of missions to and competitions running every day in which you can earn ingame currency. (Free players can enter comps too)+The RPG elements of your skills works really well as you increase your spotting, tracking and shooting skill you get real benefits from the not just higher numbers on a stats page.+Really nice and helpful community especially on the official forums.So what are you waiting for?, get started hunting now and keep in your mind that's it's free to try but to get a fuller game experience you will need a membership costing a few quid (£3-£4) a month.

content:
6, 2014
												A game that may have been state of the art ten years ago, 99% of content locked away behind very restrictive paywalls. Want to shoot some other kind of deer? 10 bucks. Want to shoot a rabbit? Sorry your starter rifle isn't permitted, how about a shotgun with birdshot for 5 bucks? There is an ingame currency that you can earn doing "missions" but that is only usable to buy limited use lures and ammunition. Weapons? Real money. Clothing? Bags? Scopes? Your credit card please. And it's not just nickel and dime stuff, weapons are 5-10 a pop and scopes start around 4.One of the few developers that hasn't figured out how to do a proper f2p model in tyool 2014. If the game didn't nag and badger you to fork over your money every five minutes and let you actually do and earn currency it would be a whole lot better and attract more customers.But before you go, even if you have terrible spending habits and don't care about throwing money away: The game isn't very good. The graphics are extremly dated, there is a hard render limit of a few hundred feet after which animals are invisible, the animations and sounds are sloppy, gunplay mediocre at best, small selection of weapons and ammo and it is missing many key features of other games such as being able to rest your weapon on anything (how can you not have this in a hunting game?!), bullet cams, whatever you could hope for.Don't waste your precious time with this unless you have some autistic need to crouch through blurry forests for hours and shoot at pixelated deer and too much disposable income. No wait, buy yourself a real hunting license for 20 bucks and go outside.theHunter, the only game more expensive to play than to do it in real life.

content:
9, 2014
												Well, for starters I can say this game has a pretty nice presentation: lush environments, a diverse and well-handled stereo soundscape, and fitting mechanics. Story is basically null, with missions in-game telling you "kill this with that" or "do these things with this animal", and that's good for the sim-feel of the game.BUT, you will at most get 3 or 4 hours out of theHunter if you don't want to pay for every single thing (weapons/gear/licenses/sights/etc.) beyond your starting kit. Once you've performed the four missions revolving around the only animal you'll be hunting in free-mode (Mule Deer), there's not much left if you don't feel like paying 4,99 euros for the next animal's license (spoiler: there are well over ten species, and the price gets steeper at every one).Sure you can wander around every reserve in the game (as a "guest" as you are referred to) and look at the gorgeous landscape, but you want to track and kill animals? Better haul out that wallet. My hope is that this gets a fixed price for the whole game, and unlockable weapons/gear as you progress in the missions. As it is now I can't recommend it, despite the hard work put into it.

content:
0, 2014
												The Good the Bad and the UglyTheHunter is a game that most people will either hate or love. I myself have developed a love-hate relationship with theHunter over the years. My first impression of theHunter was very skeptical and has grown to an absolute distrust of Expansive Worlds, the current developers. The game itself can be very addicting and enjoyable.It took me some time before I even thought it was safe to install theHunter. That's not a good first impression. TheHunter is partnered with shady marketing scams and distance themselves from all issues that arise from their use. Why would any developer tarnish their reputation before a potential customer has even been sold on a product? The reason is simple, revenue.Recently Expansive Worlds announced that they now had over 3 million accounts. To say that is a gross misrepresentation of the current status of theHunter is an understatement. If I would have to guess, I would say that active paying membership is probably in the 50,000's range. Most of the accounts are phony, not created for the intention of playing the game.So who does play this game? At its core are some long-term hunters who have invested thousands of hours and hundreds of dollars in this game. TheHunter forums are basically run by the die-hard fanatics who refuse to see the problems with Expansive World's current business practices. If you were to post this kind of feedback about the developers, you would most likely be lynched if not outright banned. Don't get me wrong, the forums are a generally mature crowd but ignorance does abound. What would you expect from humans who think it's ok to kill other animals for fun and call it a sport? Fortunately this is just a video game and we are not killing real animals. A recent poll also showed that about 50% of theHunter members are not hunters in real life.This is most definitely not a Free-to-Play  game. It is a Subscription based membership with a Micro-transaction shop. It does have a non-expiring "Demo" version which you can hunt one animal, with one weapon, in one reserve or zone, for free. Upon completion of in-game Missions you can earn enough gm$ currency to purchase one more weapon and hunt one more animal, but the ammo will run out. Though in general the gm$ earned are mostly useless without investing more real money into the game. You can potentially just play the full game  by purchasing a relatively inexpensive membership subscription and using the above mentioned "Marketing Partners" to earn enough em$, the other in-game currency, to purchase all the items in the Micro-transaction store. Again, buyer beware. At the least you may not receive the em$ and at the worse you may be infected with Spyware, Mal-ware or other potentially harmful software. And you will get no help from the developers. It should also be mentioned that you can earn em$ game currency buy winning "Competitions" but do not expect them to fund all of your desired store items. The Competitions are mainly won by having the most amount of time to spend gaming and just plain luck with a very small amount of actual skill involved, although knowledge of game mechanics are still needed.TheHunter is not a true Multi-player game in the sense of what gamers expect from today's Multi-player games. It was originally designed as a Single-player game that kept track of player statistics online, but not the game data. All of the game data resides on your local computer, there are no Multi-player servers that run the game. Because all the game data resides on the local computer you can imagine the hacking and cheating that have to be dealt with. About a year ago they decided to alter the programming to basically create a 8 player Co-op based LAN game that is hosted on the computer that starts the game. Running a Single-player game over a WAN, with no dedicated server, has introduced even more problems. So, what about the game itself? TheHunter has a beautiful environment with amazing details that can give you the feeling of actually being there. The playable areas are enormous, allowing you to spend hours at a time playing. There are 7 reserves or "zones", 18 different hunt-able animals and 33 weapons. Quite frankly there is nothing else like it.  It is a very niche game that some will find quite immersive, complex and addictive. Others will be bored stiff after a few hours. This is a very slow paced game that requires a lot of patience. Patience not only because the game play is so slow but because of poor performance and  software bugs. After many years playing, testing and reviewing video games , I have to say theHunter is one of the most enjoyed, longest running Betas (by game performance) I have ever been involved in. To be fair, the current developers at Expansive Worlds were not responsible for the original core problems implemented when the game was designed. That's not to excuse the current incompetence in management, but some of the existing problems just can't be fixed. One thing for sure is that anyone playing the game for a certain length of time will encounter serious bugs. Whether you can live with those bugs or not is an individual choice but do not expect them to be fixed. The development team is basically a Monday to Friday crew that is focused on graphical design and cosmetic items for the store. Though I am quite impressed with the single Support Staff (in the US) that handles all of the Support Requests in a professional, courteous and timely manner.I could imagine the potential of this game if it was redesigned from the ground up. Dedicated servers running multiple versions...Realistic, Arcade, Adventuring. More to do than just shoot animals. Like Botany, Camping, Hiking, Cooking, Fishing, Survival, Crafting, Etc. There are so many areas that could turn into skill based activities with achievements and accomplishments. It could be marketed to more than the niche hunter crowd. There would be no need for shady marketing and deceptive business practices. The game could be better programmed to get rid of core problems like the blinding glare of the sunlight, or the inability to cross a stream without needing an engineering degree, or  independent volume controls for things like the headache-causing-pounding-chronic rain, or not being able to look straight up or straight down and the list goes on and on. But more importantly it could fund a professional staff of developers that could provide an enjoyable game and make a profit.Alas, we have what we have. I would give theHunter a "C" rating and that's only after accepting the game for what it is, a poorly developed, perpetual Beta with a small market. Yet addictive and enjoyable. I would encourage anyone interested to try out the "Demo" and see if the game is for you.PROS:•	unique game•	vast beautiful zones•	amazing details•	endless game-play•	addictive•	worldwide player-base•	can try for freeCONS:•	poor development•	perpetual beta•	aging game•	poor performance•	lacking "gaming" features•	requires a lot of patience•	small player-base•	can be expensive

content:
, 2014
												After taking a look at the negative reviews on this game regarding it saying 'F2P' when they have a Guest user system which is essentially their version of "Free Users", I don't see why you're all upset about this. The system works perfectly with the game and despite many of you saying "You have to invest lots of cash to actually do anything", you'd be supprised if you took a look around their starter packs page and various retailers for the game (Key websites, Amazon etc), you can infact find ridiculously good deals for this title, I'll explain that further on.I myself find the game to be one of the best hunting simulators I've played in a long long time, the Cabela's series honestly has been blown away by this title and the community as it stands is in excellent condition. The game is regularly updated and despite having a few issues in the past it's turning out to be one of my all-time favourite games due to the fact that there is an unlimited amount of fun that you can have, from having hunting competitions with your friends to solo hunting in the dense forests or in the mountain peaks. The graphics and the game ballistics & physics are clean and very well-done, despite having hiccups rarely with a few glitches they need to iron out you'd be supprised at how much you can actually achieve within the game. The achievement and rewards system for competitions and general milestones are another feature which adds a sense of achievement to investing your hours into the game, same with weapon skills and tracking / spotting skill levels.On to the weapons, currency and customization within the game. Customization is somewhat limited due to the fact you can't swap camo's on your weapon, so the marketplace often has weapons of the same type but a different appearance. But it doesn't really matter as they share the same skills / stats aslong as they are the same model. Character appearance is another feature you can customize within the game by simply mix and matching clothing to your desire, with the wide range available it's really not that bad. As well as you can swap out clothing on different enviroment conditions or depending on what you're hunting to give better visibility and sound reduction stats. Currency (EM / GM) within the game is something you'd definetly expect for a game of this type. With a large multiplayer endorsement around the game I wouldn't have expected anything less than the requirement to buy different weapons, clothing and equiptment with the virtual currency, which is perfectly understandable for this title and was implemented well within the game. EM is the real-world exchanged currency where you purchase it using real-world money or you can complete surveys as an additional way of gaining it for those who can't justify supporting the title through currency purchasing. GM is the free currency which you can gain through suveys again or by completing challenges or competitions within the game, however you can purchase limited things using this currency.Honestly, despite what you guys are saying they should have no shame in calling themselves a F2P game, I've spent many hours within this game and spent what I'd say is a fairly reasonable amount on additions for the game. They offer a nice range of deals on their site for starter packs, for the price of $15 you can get almost everything you'd need to have a nice start to the game, the 12 GA Pump Action Shotgun included can hunt almost everything within the game, you gain 3 months membership and access to hunting everything and travel anywhere, as well as various other equiptment and a sidearm included.I didn't realise it before but I found various retail versions of the game available on certain retailer websites, and despite already having a membership and a nice collection of weapons, I went ahead and spent £14 on a retail key from {LINK REMOVED}♥♥♥♥♥, who offer a very nice retail package for this, for the price of any regular game. So what's the shame in calling this an F2P game if they give you a variety of free options, and then the ability to upgrade to a full version of the game with a membership / starter pack / retail copy for the price of any regular game? It's perfectly justified.And for those who are interested in that retail copy, it is beyond belief what you get from it and I'd highly recommend that to anyone interested in starting or continuing playing this game. It includes 6 months membership, 7 weapons (2 shotguns, 2 sidearms, 2 rifles, 1 bow) as well as access to everything within the game and another large assortment of equiptment and callers to get you started. (Note: One of the shotguns is an exclusive non-market shotgun too!)Weapons in the game are definetly very fitting for the title. The developers have kept far away from unrealistic hunting weapons, despite firearms such as AR-15's and semi-automatic rifles being used regularly in real world hunting they have taken the right desicion to not spoil the fun of hunting and keep it to a nice selection of rifles, shotguns, sidearms and bows. They even added a muzzleloader for those who want a way-back hunting expirence. Perfect matches, for a perfect game.Overall, in my opinion the game is absolutely superb with it's stunning graphics, unbeatable realistic physics and it's very well implemented multiplayer, community and features. Definetly a 10/10 in my books, and for those upset about the pricing of things, seriously check out the retail copies and the starter packs. For the price of a regular game (Under £15) you can get everything you need to have endless hours of fun within the game.Hopefully this was helpful, if not then I'm not sure what you were expecting from a review.(Note: Over 100 hours on the non-steam version)- Felix B.

If you can pay for it, it is okay. Or if you content yourself by subscribing and playing whit only 2 or 3 guns whit no cool equipment. It's a game for rich people. er 29, 2016
DON'T LET THE INTRO VIDEO ON THE STORE PAGE FOOL YOU. IT WOULD HAVE YOU BELIEVE THAT THE GAMEPLAY IS FLUID AND RESPONSIVE. THE MOVEMENTS ARE CRIPPLED AND LAGGY AS HELL!This one is great for when you just want to slow things down, take your time, and slaughter innocent forest creatures. Unfortunately these game devs have a horrible reputation for greed and poor customer service. They boast that it is they most realistic hunting game out there... and that's not quite true.. While the terrain and landscapes are very well done, the draw distance is very limited (meaning the animals disappear from site within a very short distance from you) in this game, and that is something that a hunting game SHOULDN'T have. The animals (excluding the deer) in the game are very poorly detailed, both aesthetically, as well as their movements. The game engine and graphics are VERY dated. If you've ever hunted in Assassin's Creed 3 or Far Cry: Primal you probably found the animals looked much better, and moved much better. The weapon handling smoother. Not to mention the superior baiting and trapping you can do in those.Then there's the business model. Not only are you required to subscribe or purchase licences (with REAL money) in order to hunt the different animals in different locations, but its also riddled with a boatload of unreasonably overpriced microtransactions for guns, ammo, nests, blinds, and pretty much EVERYTHING the game has to offer. Basically its a wring out every dollar greed fest.All from the same devs who released theHunter Primal from early access while it was (and STILL IS) very much a broken beta game, giving a nice middle finger to everyone that invested in it!Only spend money on this game if their packages on steam are at a MAJOR discount.

Online and tons of "quests"2. Great landscapes with lots of challanges, and sounds are great.3. if you love outdoor games or just hunting sim. i personally think this is the best of all i have tried!TOP 3 I DONT LIKE1. This game should not call itself F2P, cause you better get a license to enjoy it. (then a rifle :)2. some of the goat animations is a real "thumbs down" , like i was chasing one and it run 90¤ up hill.3. not much to say other than i think i have to tell you once more that its not f2p, and you should put some money into it for max pleasureSo overall points by me given are 1/10 where 10 is max.Single player experience: 10 (even a bonus since bait lures animals even when you are away)Multiplayer experience:      8 (feel like its not that much to gather from doing multi,)Graphics:                            10Developer update game:    8Developer informing us about their team and state of game: 10they have a great mail section telling us what to expect in the following month. like now "austria outback is coming" :)IS THE GAME WORTH IT?If you are going to enjoy it with friends or solo i would recommend using 20-30$ on it for all license and 1-3 rifles, and some bait, then i really recommend it! but for a F2p user its a no.. but who get a great game for free... support companies like this.OVERALL: Thumbs upMy pc specs.Screen: BenQ 27" 3D LED XL2720Z (1920x1080, 144Hz, 1ms, 12m:1, VGA/DVI/2xHDMI/DP)AMD FX (tm)-8350 Eight-Core Processor (8 CPUs), -4.0GHzNVIDIA GeForce GTX 770 (4gb Memory)24576MB Memory- Mspaint out

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
r 29, 2014
												So I got together with a couple of mates a couple days ago and we played this game for like 8 hours. I'll give you my opinion of the game.Textures - 7/10      Textures are reasonable for an open-world game, but could be better. Scripting/Execution/AI - 7/10      I'll give it descent credit because the AI is kind of detailed, but does glitch occasionally. 3D Models & Art - 8/10      The 3D modellers for this game put a lot of work into the models, which I appreciate as a game developer myself. Gameplay - ?/10      Your opinion on this game's gameplay is very dependant on your playing style and your style of game. If you play games like Call of Duty or Team Fortress than you probably won't enjoy it all that much, but if you prefer slower-paced games like Minecraft, 7 Days to Die, or like Farming Simulator, you probably will enjoy it lots. But that's just my interpretation. On another note, this game can also be incredibly boring. You could be tracking an animal for three hours and only find their feces. But that's where the slower-paced gamers come into play. If you like to play games with your friends, than I HIGHLY recommend grabbing a couple of friends and getting into a game together. It gets a lot better if you have some friends with you. Features - 0.5/10      If you've played this game before reading this review than you probably know what I'm talking about. The per month fee that you have to pay to play this game is rediculous. Sure, the game is labeled as free, but in reality all you get is a really, REALLY limited demo of the game. In this demo you get to explore about 5% of the games full map, get one weapon, and you can only hunt a small number of animals. Like one or two. Once you think about it, you end up paying like WAY more for this "free" game than any other game if you are going to play it long-term. It's $15.99 for three months of minimum game features. You can pay more for some more weapons and gear, and EVEN more for what should've been offered with the original copy of the game. And even if you don't want to get into this game long term, you can pay more actual money for face-camos and things like that and you only get about 10 uses for $0.99.Overall - 2.25/10      This game could have been incredibly succesfull and entertaining if there wasn't some scam of a fee. I understand that they want to make money for their work, but it would have been a better idea to charge maybe $10.00 or $15.00 for the full game. If you like slower-paced games and you wanted to pay $15.00 for 3 months of partial features, or nothing at all for a demo. I do not recommend this game to anybody unless you have a few friends that are willing to pay the fee as well as you.

												Love the game. Glad I found it.  It is $9.99 USD for 3 month membership. So $3.33 a month and this gets you unlimited ammo and licences for all species.  That is sort of all you need to get going.  The starter rifle .243 lets you do the mule deer missions, and when you are done them , you'll have enough in game currency to buy the single shot shotgun.  This gun is able to hunt every species in the game.Yes, not free to play, but you can hunt and do everything in the game when you get the shotgun and are a member.  I'm pretty sure they admited that was a mistake to advertise f2p.  Still awesome hunting sim.  Updated with new stuff all the time.So I recommend spending $3.33/month on this game and drop an extra $5 or $10 on it once every few months, and you'll have a great time. Just dont' buy everything at once. Buy in small amounts, there is no hurry.  It's a waiting game ;)Take care.

content:
r 2, 2014
												An absolutely emotional rollercoaster of action and suspense, this game managed to completely envelop me in its world as I fumbled with the awful controls. Once realizing my top running speed was 1.5 MPH, I was off to hunt my first deer. The journey was tough, as I crawled along, finding tracks for numerous rabbits, but no deer. Finally I was on the trail. Days and nights passed as I embarked on a quest to trudge through a forest, spamming the deer call. Finally, I was answered. A deer bleat echoed off the trees to my left, signaling that something had recieved my call. I readied my rifle, prepared for whatever awaited me past the trunks of the nearby forest. There, it stood. A beautiful, majestic mule deer waited in the pasture, looking for the source of the familiar call. I quickly tried to aim, but alas! It took off! However, this is no normal hunter you're dealing with. A well placed shot quickly dropped the animal to the ground, and I ran over to see my kill.Unfortunately harvesting the deer crashed my game.Also this game blows, seriously don't play it. If you've ever wanted to know what it's like to hunt deer as Steven Hawking, this is your game.

												ok so i download this game despite the...3,000 and some odd number of negative reviews. And to my surprise there it is, not a free to play not a free to play with slight premium buys but a pay to win, then after 3 or so months pay to win again. As soon as i loaded the game up the first screen that pops up is the purchase screen so this tells me that this is nothing but a milk machine for the skeezy developers that made this. And once i get past that i actually get into the game and what do you know i start with nothing but my hands and a camera. So upon further investigation of the getting a gun situation i find that i have to exit the game entirely and go to the "Launcher" to get equipped with something. So i knew that being a free to player i wouldn't get the best. But i got the absolute worst. I got some crappy gun that looks like it was textured in PS2 era and i still have to buy ammo which costs in-game currency. So i go to buy some and nope i got no starting cash so basically it was trying to force me to pay up to get some in game currency so i could purchase ammo for A FREE GUN. I feel like this should be labeled as a bad game and taken off steam due to the 3,000 some odd number negative reviews saying it was a horrible game and nothing but a scheme to rob people. I am going to try and contact the developers to see if i did something wrong and how i can fix it and i might change my review.

content:
6, 2014
												Here's how it basically works:-Each animal needs a license to be hunted. You can't have permanent licenses. You can buy membership to have all licenses for 3 - 6 - 12 months.-You can hunt animals only with the right rifles, meaning if you buy the license for Bear hunting but you don't have a weapon that's good for it then you can't hunt it.-F2P = license to hunt Mule Deer and Rabbit, 1 weapon with which you can hunt Mule Deer but not Rabbit. Unlimited ammo for that weapon, a scope and a Mule Deer "caller" ( idk how to call it i'm not native english )-You need to buy ammos for weapons. Meaning if you buy a shotgun then you need to buy it's ammos. When you finish the ammos ( 2 euros are usually 10-20 ammos  depends on the ammo type ) then you need to buy other ammos.-Every rifle costs from 5 to 20 euros.-Clothes, "callers" for other animals, and all that ♥♥♥♥ that helps you have a easier hunt cost real money.Definitely not a real F2P, don't even download it if you're not ready to spend A LOT of money.

9, 2015
												I must say this is the best hunting game out there!Pros:pretty realisticgreat gfxa great varity of animals to hunt, weapons and gear to use. Cons:MONEY!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!I understand its a F2P but the ONLY way to hunt anything fun is to pay for a sub for x amount of months, then depending on what you want to hunt you have to have certain weapons and/or gear to hunt them. This also costs money to get and a TON of it...... You can do objectives that gives you in game money, but this only buys you scents, lures, bait, pretty much consumables. In all honesty if you like hunting games this is the game for you as long as you have a good $50+ to spend on getting guns, clothing, calls, stands, sites/scopes. If you don't have any money to put into the game its not worth getting due to the fact you CAN'T hunt anything fun.

content:
, 2014
												The Hunter is the best hunting game there is. No questions, it looks great, it plays smooth and is realistic!It does not have a long and hard learing cruve, you have a "Hunter mate" that can tell you what tracks it is that you just found and tell you where the track is leading. For me it took like 3 - 4 hours to really get the hang of the game. Now, as a "free" user you only get to hunt (i think its 2 not sure) 2 animals and you get 2 weapons. You get one hunting reserve that is huge. If you want to play the other 7 reserves and hunt all the 18 animals you need a subscribtion. When i started playing this game i first played as a free user and hunted for 1 hour per day just to see if i enjoyed it that much that i would like to pay for it. And i did! So i bought the 300kr (29 euros approx) package that gave me 6 months sub, a ♥♥♥♥ tons of weapons and equpiment. When my sub was gone, i still had all my weapons and equimpent left, so i just bought another 3 months for 80kr (8-9 euros) and started to play again. There is a lot of stuff you can buy ingame, for example callers, baits and camo. I have used the regular outfit for more than a year and been able to hunt in every reserve and any animal with out problem. Its just for looks and making hunting a little bit easier (even though i think its funnier to just follow tracks and shoot them, some perfeer to sit near an open field with a caller and wait for somthing to show up). Anyway should you get this game? Install it and try as a free user. If you liked it, I recommend the 30 euro package, it gives you (in my opinion) the best rifle and some equipment.

content:
4, 2014
												well,  to be honest, the hunter could be a really awesome hunting simulator.COULD BE.on the positive side:  - many interesting and well designed locations.- detailed and pretty looking graphics, good looking animations, shadows and light effects.- realistic animal and gun sounds.- very far distant view.- changing weather conditions.on the negative side:- some video bugs, like floating trees, poo...- the water, especially in rivers looks rather ugly.- you cant host multiplayer games without buying a membership subscription.- you see many different animal species, but you arent allowed to shoot them without "a license" aka a membership subscription.- 90% of the time you're tracking an animal with a device called "huntermate", you see a popup "YOU FOUND A TRACK OF A XXX BUT YOU DONT CURRENTLY OWN THE LICENSE OR MEMBERSHIP TO HUNT IT"  thats just ♥♥♥♥ing annoying.i understand that its a free to play game, and the developers want to earn money, but this license / membership system is really one of the worst i found after years of gaming.i would gladly pay 50€ ONE TIME to get the hunter as full game, with all guns, equipment, when im able to hunt all animals...but with this "free demo, pay when you want a real game"-system, its a big NO for me.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
y 24
												a honest review from a person that has put a total of $9.98 in to the game for 3 things, a 10X rifle scope, deer grunt call, and the 270 bolt action rifle that turned out to be useless because I just found out that I'll either need to keep buying the ammo for it or buy a subscription to keep ammo for it.I would like to recommend this game but I can't because its pay to progress in most cases, I mean yes of course there are payed things in the game because the dev needs to make money off of the free to play module but the way the dev are using the free to play module, the non paying people are extremely limited. fun game but extremely limited if you don't spend the money.if you don't spend a dime expect to get the followingable to hunt Whitetail Deer, Pheasant, Cottontail Rabbit, European Rabbit and Snowshoe Hare.You get a .243 Bolt Action Rifle (Wood) (and 243 carbon if you confirm your email) and a Single Shot Shotgun for free.You get free ammunition for the two weapons above.As a guest you are free to explore any reserve you like in single player mode.You may also join multiplayer gamesYou can participate in Competitions and complete Missions (missions must be reset with real money after completing them all)if you don't spend a dime expect to not get the followingAs a guest you cannot host multiplayer parties.Guests cannot take in-game profile shots (avatars). They are limited to the standard avatars.Guests have a limited trophy shot functionality. They cannot pose the animal's body, and they cannot pose their hunter character along with the animal.note: if you buy a weapon you'll either have to buy a subscription membership of 3,6 or 12 months or keep buying ammo for the weapons you bought that are not premium. premium ammo for premium weapons you'll need to buy more ammo regardless of your membership status

content:
16, 2016
												I recommend this more for the views you get while playing. I love the environments and how it's built. However, I don't recommend spending a cent on this game for new items. The only way you can rank high in this game is by spending tons of money for the best guns and sights. I only buy a license with the money you win from missions. However, this money doesn't last forever, and the missions will eventually require weapons that can only be bought the EMs, not GMs. EM's are either won from competitions or bought with money (for those who don't know and are confused).I can play this game fine and be happy with only killing mule deer and some rabbits, but I would love to go to other areas and hunt there. It is rare that a promo comes along that allows free killing. The license you buy only lasts a few days, so you need to buy it on a week that you know for a fact you can make good use of it (in other words, a few days that you have nothing to do but hunt constantly). If you buy the license at a not-so-great time, it's a complete waste.But I do stand strongly by the fact that this game is fun and has an awesome view. I just strongly recommend you save your cash and stick to mule deer and rabbits. Buy the one or two shotguns that can be bought for GM's and go crazy on those bunnies!

												theHunter is definitely my new addiction. The graphics are just purely amazing and also the gameplay is really well done. 												after playing this ♥♥♥♥ game for a few hours, i've decided to review it.First off, the game looks great, and its fun to play; But at the same time you ARE limited to what you can do without premium. There are 2 kinds if in game currecy, one being em$ (premium funds) and the other gm$ (earnable funds). -em$: This currency you earn by buying it. it can in turn buy guns (rifles, pistols, shottys, ect.), attatchments (scopes... thats it i think), hunting licences (duh), and other USEful things. -gm$: This currency you can earn by doing missions. It can in turn buy facepaint, certain cover scents, and hunting licences (timed period) +Pros: good looking, fairly fun, consumes time well.-Cons: its P2Wdownload it if you want, but unless you have any money to throw away, dont...

The Hunter is a great time waster. Your goal is simple: track down and hunt animals. This could very well be the perfect hunting simulator. The graphics' gorgeous! The gameplay is great. The community is very helpful. So, this is definitely a very fun game to play. The only drawback is the price you have to pay. Yes this game is free to download but in order to fully enjoy it, you'd have to pay for at least a 3-month membership. If they're offering the licenses as a one-time purchase then i won't have any issues buying the game. But for people like me who won't really be playing everyday, i don't think the prices for subscription's worth it. But hey, I still recommend this game because you can still enjoy the game without the membership. You just have to be really patient.

												I've been playing The Hunter since before steam, this is my first review of The Hunter. The Hunter's developers are extremely money hungry and all they want to do is to make this game a "free to play" and add items you have to buy with REAL MONEY. It is just like team fortress 2, but TF2 has much, much less items you have to pay for, and most of them are 3 dollars. in The Hunter, you have to pay for almost EVERY item in the game. You even have to buy a damn membership for hunting additional animals. Guest membership can only shoot mule deer and cotton-tail rabbit, and the default weapon isnt licensed for THE DAMN RABBIT, which means you need to BUY a gun that is designed for rabbits.. ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥T! Do NOT buy any item they have, it is a waste of money, or better yet, DON'T PLAY THE GAME!!'

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
, 2014
												By far one of the best hunting games you will ever find period! Yes it sucks you have to actually buy licenses and rifles and such but in this day and age you should expect it and compared to paying $30 for an arcade cabellas game every few months its worth it. The 3 month is $15 and that is crazy cheap for an online multiplayer game. As for the game itself. The maps are beautiful and very detailed, most hunting games are either open fields or forrests that seem more like a crop or plantation. Wide selection of firearms and bows, you don't need every single one you can get one rifle and one shotgun and hunt everything in the game, or just one bow. The animals can be a challenge to track more so the trophy animals they are very skiddish as they should be. Too many people are focusing and giving bad reviews on the fact that this game isnt really "free". I have news for you. It is. You never have to buy the game. Yes you have to put a few bucks in here and there to get everything the game has to offer but you dont HAVE to do that if you don't want. Some people just like hunting mule deer... That is FREE... Ammo for the .243 is FREE, You want to go hunt whitetail then pay a couple bucks and get a license or pay $15 and get it for 3 months.If this game does not suit you then go back to Cabellas games. They are great if you like to hunt like you are playing CoD and not actually hunting.

content:
y 9
												With theHunter Call of the wild coming out I decided to give this game a shot, and its the best hunting game out there. Gameplay wise in the first 3 or 4 hours+ wich it takes to get a decent mule deer its pretty interesting.. I mean if you shoot at anything yes sure the game dies out quick. but if you really try to aim to get a "Trophy" Kill its not that bad..They have also added 1 more animal to shoot so you can shoot 3 free animals, White tail Deer, Some bird, and another animal + they went to add the Moba style "Free to play" Licenses where every week you get a free license.. This week there is Bison for example... Sadly tho, in cold weather you need cold weather clothes and this game is not exactly free to play. you can now also go to other reserves where you can find your desired animals, so you can for example go and kill a mule deer but at the same time you can spot a bear or a moose.. Quite interesting. I didnt mention the cash shop since everyone knows already that its a terrible cash shop, hence why they are making a "buy to play game called "The hunter call of the wild" And honestly if this game is anything like the Hunter, i dont wanna give it a negative review, because the ONLY negative thing about this game is the cash shop and i think that any negative review can Agree on that.. This game is actually very fantastic if you immerse your self in it, or you chase the same deer for 4km because its a BIG ♥♥♥♥ING DEER! but big ♥♥♥♥ing deers means big ♥♥♥♥ing experience so he probably thinks "That is one hella noobish hunter, i can trick this guy across the map!" Fantastic game, Horrible cash shop.. I'll give it a 10/10 for immersion10 / 10 hunting sim10 / 10 gameplay (its a bit old now but still solid)-10/10 Cash shopOverall 3/10 (99% due to cash shop).. Fantastic game honestly CANT wait for the call of the wild!

												I'm going to start off by saying this game has a lot of potential to be an amazing hunting simulator. The fact that is multiplayer is also a fun bonus. The false advertising rubbed me in all the wrong ways however; this game is not free to play (unless you like a hiking simulator dressed up as a hunting simulator). To actually hunt in this game you have to spend real money on licenses, guns, etc. I'm hoping in the future that this game will actually allow you to hunt a bit more without spending money (or just costing money right off the bat). This game does have a lot of promise but right now I wouldn't waste your time downloading it.

content:
er 20, 2014
												(I have played this game since around 2011 when it was a single player game and even before it came to Steam, in total I have a few hundred hours played)THERE IS A TUTORIAL. If you can't find it yet still somehow start a hunt, don't play it. You clearly don't have the chops for this game, sorry.Let me open this up by saying if you're under 16 or have some kind of attention deficit disorder, stay away. If you're the kind of person whom while playing MMOs jumps on your mount to run 10 meters and tries to hit max level on the first day\week, stay away. If you're the kind of person who thinks games like the ArmA franchise are 'boring' stay away. If you're the kind of person who thinks 'Free to Play' should mean: "Give me everythig in a week so I can move on to the next game like a ravenous locust" stay away. If you can't take the time to read a few pages of text, stay away.This game requires an insane amount of patience, forethought and time. It requires you to learn animal behaviours, how to use lures. It'll teach you how to stalk, stay down-wind and it'll teach you to ease off the trigger and wait for that pefect shot. But it won't beat it into you. If you don't learn, you'll never kill anything, and you'll blame the game for your own hysterical ineptitude.The game is your typical huting style game, you enter a range with a few buddies, gear up and go looking for game. If you're an idiot and run around everywhere, you'll hear nothing and see less. See my point above: Go low, go slow. Follow the trails the animal has left. Spot it's calls and get yourself in range for a quick, clean effcient and ethical kill. Simple right? It's an especially enjoyable just chilling in a tower or a hide with a few buddies catching up.Now let's talk about the pay wall, shall we? Yes the game is hardly playable as a free to play game. Is it prohibitivly expensive? Only if you're an idiot with no idea how to take advantage of bundles. There are a selection of bundles on the store that offer 3, 6 and 12 month subs respectivly alongside a whole boat load of gear. If you drop the £30 on the top end back you get:12 Month SubAround £50 worth of consumablesA weapon from each catagory and a high powered pistol, as well as ammo and equipment for it.GearHidesStandsTentsThis is as much conent as if you'd bought the game normally. CRAZY I KNOW. It's almost like the company wants to stay in business with such a small demograph. (Let's hope these kids never spot Flight Sim after market prices, eh?)Yet the people knocking this game are more than happy to drop £60 on the latest CoD Map Pack while shouting about this games payment model. It is MORE than possible to buy a single 3 month sub and complete the missions in a few days, giving you around 100,000 GMS (In game currency) which is enough to buy liscences and hunt for free for around a year and a half.)Make no mistakes though, the Free to Play in this game should be considered a pretty hefty, unlimited demo, much like WoWs Free to Play model.If you've ever wanted to actually hunt or want a realistic representation of what it could be like, this game, some buddies and a few hours to kill will be a rewarding and satisfying experience. If you want to have a collection of 30 deer pelts and wrestle a bear all within 10 minutes, don't waste your time, or my time when you come crying to the forums.

content:
r 5, 2014
												The game in itself is ok. The character is really slow tho! He takes forever to aim the weapons, very unrealisticly so to! But over all the actual game is good enough. However it is REALLY expencive! You have to pay a subscription that is way to expencive for this game, AND you have to pay for nearly every in-game item, from weapons, clothes to ammunition, They advertise that there is an in-game currency, but this is almost worthless, you can't by mutch with it, and you don't get mutch of it either. If you want to unlock new stuff, you have to pay real money. Playing this game for a year is only slightly less expencive than hunting IRL. And I can't emphazise how slow the character is! The running/walking thing is ok, but the aiming, sighting, and operating of the weapons are so increadible slow! I've seen people that never fired a weapon before do it twice as fast. I can get of 5-6 rounds before this guy can fire two, and I have only shot a pump shotgun for less than 6 months.

content:
ry 19, 2015
												Lets talk anout the pay to win....In order to hunt anything other than Mule deer and Rabbit(non-members dont get a shotgun for rabbit) you need a membership or a specific licence.I don't entirely agree with this system, it causes you to have to pay a lot of real money over time as opposed to just paying money for the game and being able to get all the in-game stuff without real money.All of this aside, the gameplay is amazing, it strikes a good balence between simulation/realism and enjoyment. Most animals are not so hard that you get extremely bored (as long as you're hunting correctly) yet some of them can be tricky to hunt. They each have they're own habitat,(some are in more than one reserve)sounds, difficulty, and weapons that you can use for them.(don't worry about having to buy a ton of guns for all of the animals)Overall, if you can put up with the payment system, and you have some patience. This game is extremely fun to play.

ber 23, 2014
												This game is quite litteraly the worst F2P game ever. I didnt know about lisences first, until I tried to find a map that didnt have animals I couldnt hunt. Turns out to be the most boring forest ever. Nothing there really, and half the animals on the island I couldnt hunt because some creep 5 Miles high was watcing me, putting on a remote safty on the gun when I aimed at an animal I didnt have the lisence for.ANIMALSQuite well done, if only I got to see them. I would pick up a trail, following it for hours, (Really, I spent two whole waste-of-time hours hunting a mule deer) then it would run away before I got to see it. It was quite fustrating. Oh, and you only get to hunt the Mule Deer and the Cottontail rabit. Why? Because you need lisence. And if you shot the rabbit with a .243 Rifle, you dont get anything. You need to buy a shotgun that really aint worth it.SCENERYI actually liked the areas and vistas, but the only map that had an abboundance of Mule Deer was some stupid quickly-done-like-a-painter-on-steriods area in the middle of nowhere. It was really pathetic.FIREARMSWanna quickscope a Deer in the face? You cant. It will instantly hear from a mile away and you take about 2-3 seconds to scope in, and the scope wobbles around like crazy. Only one other gun you can buy with GM$, as the rest (Pistols, Revolvers, Multi-Shot Snipers(Yours is one shot) etc etc) are EM$ (Pay to get).SUMMARYThis game is quite lucdorious, as I found more animals I couldnt hunt then animals I could. It throws you into the game with crud all, making you more tempted to buy PREMIUM!!!!! and thats what bothers me. About 3 days later, I was out of missions that I could do. And that meant paying up the dough. (in which I didnt) Well at least you can play with your friends, right? Wrong. You need PREMIUM!!!!!, and if you dont wanna pay up then go onto some creepy weird who is always disturing your prey and is shooting your friend non-stop.

Only one other gun you can buy with GM$, as the rest (Pistols, Revolvers, Multi-Shot Snipers(Yours is one shot) etc etc) are EM$ (Pay to get).SUMMARYThis game is quite lucdorious, as I found more animals I couldnt hunt then animals I could. It throws you into the game with crud all, making you more tempted to buy PREMIUM!!!!! and thats what bothers me. About 3 days later, I was out of missions that I could do. And that meant paying up the dough. (in which I didnt) Well at least you can play with your friends, right? Wrong. You need PREMIUM!!!!!, and if you dont wanna pay up then go onto some creepy weird who is always disturing your prey and is shooting your friend non-stop.

content:
6, 2016
												From what I understand, the free-to-play portion of the game has become more expansive with a rotating roster for free locations and licenses.I personally pay for the game; bought a starter pack to get a few months of unlimited licenses, unlimited ammo, and a bunch of permanent weapons. I have really enjoyed it. I even added on a few months more and enough virtual currency for an additional firearm I was curious about.I haven't been counting, but my guess is I've paid around $50 or so and already have about 100 hours of gameplay. Not to mention I have multiple months left on my current subscription. With the experience this game gives you, I feel like that is money well spent. Not the biggest bang-for-buck (womp womp), but definitely worth it.No, it's not going to provide the consistant action of Doom or Serious Sam. You spend time tracking, luring and stalking animals that respond to the scent (with wind), auditory and visual cues that you provide.Can you spend 3 hours tracking a bear that you never see because it can hear you before you pick up on its tracks? Yes.Can you spend 2 hours luring turkeys before you find one that fits your mission objective? Yes.Are there missions where you're supposed to just spot some tracks? You betcha.Is it worth it? I think so.I've never been out hunting in the real world so I cannot attest to the accuracy; but I do enjoy the experience this game provides as well as the patience it teaches me.

content:
ry 11
												Ok. I have now hit around the 100 hour mark in this game and its time to review it. Does this game deserve 40% negative review? short answer: NO. Long answer: Still no, but I understand why its so low. This game is advertized as a "free to play" game. This is sadly not the case. This is a pay to play Hunting simulator. And let me tell you, this is the single best hunting game ever made. Hands down the most fun and imersive hunting experience I have ever had the pleasure to enjoy. I love this game and always will. TheHunter classic will be a game I come back to again and again for two reasons. 1) Like I said above this game gets hunting right. From big game to small the team at EW has done an amazing job creating beutifull hunting reserves inhabited by great looking and beliveable animals to hunt. Its a blast to shoot bucks and ducks alike.2) I have spent too much money not to get the most out of this game. I think I am sitting at about a $250 bill when it is all said and done. From guns, blinds, lures, callers, bait stations, tents and any hunting equipment you could think of I have bought something of it. But here is why this game is sitting at 40% negative on steam review.The majority of reviews here are from people who downloaded the game, played for a hour and quit and uninstalled when they saw what is free in the game. Which is not very much. You can always hunt for free with licences for Whitetail deer, all the rabbits and pheasant's. They also give you the means to hunt all of these animals. For free equipment you get the .243 bolt action rifle, 12ga single shot shotgun (not free when I started years ago by the way, bonus for new players now!) and unlimited free ammo for both guns. You also get binoculars, deer bleet caller and a camera to take pics with. You as a free user can also join other hosts multiplayer games but you yourself can't host a game without membership. You can complete missions for specific animals and earn in-game money to buy consumables with. You cant get any weapons with the mission money. You can however earn the premium curency by entering and winning competitions (you are unlikely to win so I dont really count this). By now many people will already not want to bother trying this game if you have read this far. Try it anyways. Trust me here you cant get some really fun hunting done with what you have a free user. Its basicly a demo so why not give it a try and see if you like it. And if you do like the game then buy a membership package. I recomend the $54 one that gives you a year of licences to hunt all animals and a bunch of new weapons and equipment to get you a really good start. With that package you dont really need to buy anything else to get the full experience out of the game.Here are some tips to get free stuff in game (dont say the devs never gave you anything).By verifying your email you get a free rifle. Do that in your account info in the launcher. Aslo if you send a referal link to a friend (find that in the launcher sidebar) and they make a TheHunter account you get a ground blind free and your friend gets premium curency and some free equipment. So get a friend to try with you, and if they decide to buy a membership  package (you will get the following rewards depending on what package they buy) you get a premium engraved .308 rifle, engraved deer "grunt" caller and a two person tree stand all for free. Also in steam there is a free dlc equipment package that gives you a bunch of consumables for no cost.

er 24, 2016
												Ok, the F2p bit is stretching it a bit far since you only get 2 free weapons and ammo at the beginning which does allow you to hunt various animals, but all being said; it is value for money.The 3mth membership alone you don't find in most games, and ok you have to buy the weapons but tbh since you earn gm's for the ammo you're laughing.This is not a game to waste your money on as you can waste your money quite quickly. It is what it says on the tin, The hunter, you hunter; them animals; you hunt and get better at hunting. All you need to get going is your Computer or Laptop, your Mouse and a lot of your Patience, have them and you're already on your way to be a hunter. And there is plenty in the game to keep you interested:Hunting records :Hunting statsHunting SkillsHunting AchievementsInventorial:Plenty of weapons to get your hands onPlenty of modifications (Weapon specific)Gameplay:As realistic Hunting as you will ever get in a game (Anywhere)Plenty updates to the game to maximise realisticness and upkeeping of the players experiences. (if something goes wrong, it is quickly sorted or as quick as they can get to it)Experience:Really helpful players when you need help or advice on the game etc..Really helpful SupportThese are some of what the game gives but there is a lot more in the game than i can be bothered to put in here as it would take too much time to do so.Updated from here:So far things have been hotting up within the game:New eventsNew seasonal events and challengesNew animalsNew reserveNew weaponsNew gearFixing of things needing fixed and not trying to fix what is not brokenThis game has definitely a long way to go and it can only get better.

content:
8, 2015
												I've been playing the free version since 2009 when my PC could barely run it. Now I've got a much beefier PC and decided to take the plunge and buy a membership. $54(CAD) for the Trailrunner starter pack (Best deal IMO) gives you a very nice selection of weapons/equipment, and all licenses for a year.All I can say is wow. I'm not dissappointed at all with my purchase. I love the fact that this game is 6 years old and still amazing. At first I wasn't a fan of the whole "pay-to-play" sales model, but I completely understand why the dev's did it that way.If this game was a "buy once and keep playing" type of game it would have been released in 2009, and stayed in basically the same shape it was is at the time of release.Instead, we've got a game that is constantly being updated, even 6 years after it's initial release, and that's due to the fact that the devs are still seeing an income from the game, which allows them to spend time/resourses updating it, and adding fresh new content, as well as fix bugs and add new features over time.In my opinion, that makes it worth the $34(CAD) I need to keep paying in order to hunt all the animals after my licenses expire.Don't get me wrong, if I decide to not pay next year, I can still keep all of the weapons/equipment that came with my initial purchase and use them to hunt Mule Deer and Cottontails (I believe those are the only free animals), but I will definitely be buying my licenses again next year.I would even consider buying a higher priced "lifetime license" if the devs ever thought to release something like that, but I understand why they decided to go with the current business model.Now, if only they would do something similar with theHunter:Primal so it could be anywhere close to as amazing of a game as this is.

content:
8, 2014
												The gameplay is amazing. I really dig it. Walking trough the woods. with a pair of buddies. tracking an animal together. listening to animals calls trying to find the one you're looking for. But. Theres a big but.The buissness model is simly awful. this should not be in the free to play section. but in a new section called Free to Pay. As the game will try to squeeze every penny it can out of you. What you do get for free. is a low caliber bolt action hunting rifle. With unlimited ammunition. a pair of binoculars. and a little bit of camping supplies for fast travel (consumables) The game features two currencys. Quite usual for the Free to play market. Yet also has a subscription! And one does not grant you the olther! Subscription or "Membership" Will grant you a "License" To hunt all animals. But the rifle you start with is not "Ethical" for all of them. thus you will have to spend even more money to actually take part in competitons. or get score for theese animalsEM$: A currency used to get absolutly everything the ratio is 100 EM$ = Dollar. But the smallest package you can buy is 500. for 5 dollars. the larger packages save you a little bit of cash. EM$ Is the currency used to buy about anything. Clothing. weapons and so on. Yet a single item will cost you 3-7 dollars. For just a single item. "Happy Camper tents" Will cost you 550 EM. But there is no 550 Package. Forcing you to spend more money!While there are competitions in game with EM Prizes. To get to them. you will most likely have to spend money. Again!GM$: An in game currency. You might think that you get GM from hunting animals. And you'd be wrong. All you get is score. in a phatetic attempt to squeeze more money out of you. GM is earned by compleating missions. theese have a finite number. and most of them require you to use a peticular weapon or hunt an animal you will not have acsess too. without opening your wallet up. And do not ague that the microtransaction system lets you have "Choice" As it does not. The design of the game. maps. liceances. all of that is under the influance to squeeze more MONEY out of you wallet. And it will not stop untill you have everything. And once you do. They will still try and squeeze money out of you on a monthly basis. EIther have microtransactions. or a subscription. having both is disgusting.

Would recommend for mild ammusement for a couple hours but certainly not any kind of real investment in either time or money.

content:
6, 2014
												The really astounding thing about this game is how much fun it could be if the company at the reigns wasn't so money grubbing and stupid. It's actually kind of fun to run around, explore, etc. It reminds me of STALKER, only filled with deer and rednecks instead of muties and Russians.But you get nothing. You get absolutely nothing as a starting player. The only thing you can hunt are mule deer and rabbits, but you can't even kill the rabbits with your rifle. Great decision there. The clothes you start with are vastly inferior to the ones you can only get with money. Which would be fine, but you can't upgrade at all without money. At all. You can't get any weapons, clothes, etc.The game says you can 'earn' currency by doing surveys and such. This is an absolute load. Every single site it links you to is sketchy as hell. Some of the 'programs' it wants you to download are blatant viruses that only an idiot would use. Nice. Of all the offers I went through ( most of them viruses or dead links that did nothing ), I managed to complete one. I got nothing. The currency never came. Even if you pay for the game, it's so damn stingy that you're basically going to need to spend money to keep playing. It's absolutely baffling just how much this company hates it's potential players and wants to squeeze every last cent out of them. This isn't free to play. This is a demo. It shouldn't even be in the free to play section.The only reason you should even consider this game is if you want something to space out to while you're listening to an audiobook or doing something important.

												As of me typing out this review i have been playing for 3 weeks and i have to say the devs of this game have come a long way and yes the there might be a few bugs here and there the devs work their butts off to fix them as fast as they can.In this review i would like to pint out a few things(1) Yes you do need to pay money to actually be able to hunt the majority of the species but i would like to point out that in order to hunt in real life you need to buy a license as well.(2) Just like in real life hunting you need to take your time and be patient in order to drop that big buck or bull you might have been tracking. In no way shape or form will you just get that big buck or moose in the first few minutes of you joining a server. This game focuses on developing skills such as spotting and tracking and the more these skills are developed ingame the more proficient you become as a hunter just like you would IRL.(3) This game will appeal more to those who truely respect and/or love for the great outdoors. So therefore if you treat this game as a real life hunt you wont even notice you are actually playing a game.overall thoughts on this game:fantastic simulator that should be given a score of 10/10

content:
2, 2014
												It's a good game - don't get me wrong. It's immersive, tense, beautiful, and fun. Tracking is an absolute thrill as well. It's a game I'd gladly pay $15-20 for. However, it's free to play, but not in a good sense. In order to have any real fun after the first hour or two, you'll need to pay ridiculous fees. You wanna hunt something besides mule deer and rabbits? You need to buy liscences with real money for individual animals. Even better, the liscences aren't even permanent! Plus, you need to buy lures, scents, camouflage, and even AMMO! On the "plus side" you can allow companies to fill your computer up with malware for some free ingame cash. TL;DR, it'd be great without tons of arbitrary paywalls

content:
28, 2014
												It's my first hunting simulation, I really enjoy it and there are a lot of things you can learn from its wiki wich lead you, for example, to a real scoring for mule deers or any other information you didn't know about some species. It is very interesting for those who love hunting simulations. It's realistic, the environment you are in is important in relation to the animal you are hunting and if you miss a move, they're gone but you still can find them later with the track they leave behind. Also, there are a lot of places to go and the maps are big enough to trip trough forests and water.Why don't I recommend this game?Because if you want a good equipment, you need to spend a lot of real money or spend some time on third-party pages (eather you earn a little or not... yes, some links does not simply reward you). Well, you earn some virtual cash when you finish a mission but, you can not even buy a thing that is worth your work and time in-game. I don't even know how dare they call this game a F2P. When you are a beginner and don't want to give a few bucks, the only thing that can be done is tracking or kill one of the 18 species (you must have licenses for them ->money) with a single default rifle and there are a lot of missions to do but you can't complete them because you don't really want to spend your own money on that...Again, it's a very interesting game but the store and monetary system in-game made me sick...
