content:
, 2014
												Just no, for the first few hours you do get a slight buzz, and it really does interest me but, after these hours the game just stops. This seriously disappointed me as i soon realize what you need to get a full immersive action: a membership of 3, 6 or 12 months, other guns as (the one you are given is only allowed to be used on a few animals), scopes for the guns and ammunition these all have a sizable price tag and i haven't even mentioned clothes and other addons to make the hunting easier. this may sound like a rant, and it probably is, but it is just annoying that they claim to be a free to play(by definition, a game which gives players access to a significant portion of their content without paying) which is clearly not fufliled in this supposedly free to play game and the developers should be quite ashamed in portraying it to be so (reading through the features they have given, there is no mention of only being able to shoot one animal and only limited to one park for guest).on the other hand if you are willing to pay on the region of $40 to have enjoyable experience then i am sure you will have a great experience, but withn the next few months or maybe a year you will have to pay another $20 or more to kepp you going on the bare minimum or to get the next urgrade, gun or membership.back on to those who do not want to pay, like me, you should download this game; just to see if you like it because it is your decision which is the ultimate decider, but do not come into this game thinking you will get a sizeable portion of content as you will be severly disappionted. This is a good game in theory and with the willing to pay constant money, but it underacheives what is expected of an average F2P.

number of helpful: 8 of 14 people (57%) found this review helpful
content:
er 7, 2014
Day one::I was roaming and couldn't find a single animal for nearly an entire hour. I found some tracks and went in a full circle, tracking multiple rabbits and deer. Not a single animal was found.Day two: :I tracked some feral hogs down. While trying to noscope them, they rammed me. My bloodied and bruised rolled down a hill while I was injured. That was fun.Day three: :I spotted a rock. I named him Jim. Jim was a floating rock. He could fly away to the stars if he wanted to. But he didn't want to.Day four: :I found three rabbits - All of which fled like ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥. They didn't even challenge my noscoping capabilities. One of them even strolled right infront of me as I was writing this down. What a prick.Day five: :I located several coyotes. I channeled my inner Sonic and ran like hell, if hell had a moped. I then assumed I would never catch anything without being injured and started shooting the butterflies. They were even harder to shoot. I concluded that the trees, grass and rocks would be my safest hunting targets for the next week or so. I could simply live off their profitable and highly nutritious entrails.Day six: :I found a flock of pheasents. Yes. This will be my one and only chance.. Steady.. Steady.. FI- Wait, I can't shoot pheasents..? Well, I better go live off of Jim and his family again.Day seven: :I decided to screw the intention of this game and simply enjoy the scenic views, the beautiful colors, the delicious deer right infront of m- SHOOT IT NOW.The only thing I wanted to shoot after playing this game was myself.

												I never review game, but I feel like I have to do it on this one, seeing all the bad reviews it is getting, mostly because of the "Free to play" tag. First, if you want this game to be fun, the "Free to play" tag does not apply. The free part is only useful to make sure you can run the game and get a glimpse of what it is.I started playing this game a while ago from its web page (around 130hrs) and continued on Steam since I got Windows 10. I spent around 60$ so far and I'm well equipped to hunt everything in every reserve, or almost; my friend have bought different guns/deployable items than I did, so we didn't "double buy" anything and we can do 99% of missions and hunt ducks and geeses comfortably, which are the most expensive to hunt. Anyway, lots of fun to hunt in all the reserves with friends or strangers or even alone. Great variety of species, good graphics, competitions and leaderboards to get the adrenaline up when you think this is the big buck you were waiting for!I think you have to consider it like a normal game you usually pay between 40$ to 60$ (bundles of several months of  membership and additional guns and stuff available, or buy points to get what you want separatly) and you will have lots of hours of good hunting. After that, when you membership ends, you choose to renew it for another 3 months (3-4$/month) or not, but if you really like hunting games, I bet you will!In the end, if money is really an issue, this game is not for you

												The Hunter is a hunting simulator where your goal is to simply collect the highest scoring animal (in short).It features a wide range of animals to hunt from small game to big game in different environments.This combined with new daily competitions to win trophies and in-game cash creates a fun and non-repetitive experience.It is also being constantly updated with new gear, animals and places to hunt at, and if you don't like playing alone there's also multiplayer. content:
, 2014
												A few years ago I was searching the Internet for hunting games and I stumbled upon theHunter. I played the game for a fairly long time, since it was a one of a kind hunting simulation. First I started as a guest (it's a kind of trial membership) but I became bored pretty fast, since you only can hunt one species (mule deer) and only have one gun. If you're willing to pay for a real membership, you can hunt all the species in the game and also get a couple weapons and unlimited ammunition for them.Eventually the company behind theHunter became kinda greedy and that changed the whole game literally. If you want to enjoy the whole game and want to take part in all competitions, you have to invest a good amount of money. For example, you don't have to buy every single weapon but then you'll have a limited selection of competitions you can participate in. You don't have to buy every lure or whatever but then you have a disadvantage against other players, who bought all the stuff you're not willing to buy and use.Long story short: The "free" version of the game is just a playable demo in my opinion. If you really want to have fun in theHunter, you'll have to invest a good amount of real money. Other reviews already mentioned the prices, so I won't go into that in my review. If you're willing to do so, you'll get the best hunting simulation you can get at the moment. It's nothing like any other hunting game out there. Here you'll get a simulation for your money and not just another Cabe*** arcade type of game.Unfortunately, I have to give this game a thumbs down, since it became way too expensive to enjoy in it's fullest.

number of helpful: 12 of 22 people (55%) found this review helpful
content:
, 2014
												I have been into PC hunting games since the mid 90’s. Then in 1997 Deer Hunter brought it all to 3D. I have owned and played every game in that series from Deer Hunter in 1997 up to Deer Hunter Tournament in 2008 also Trophy Hunter 2003. Then I caught word of a new revolutionary hunting simulation that was in development called theHunter. They have taken PC hunting simulation into the next generation with its release back in 2009. Players have 7 large hunting reserves to choose from that range from open fields to deciduous and evergreen forest also from spring/summer environments to fall and winter. Free to play members can hunt mule deer and cottontail rabbit (2 of the 18 species available) on 2 different reserves. theHunter is new to Steam and a lot of people who seem to think that the gaming industry revolves around Steam also think that if it’s new on Steam then it is new everywhere. This is not the case. theHunter went live sometime back in 2009. Avalanche created a child company called Expansive Worlds solely to further develop theHunter. This shows that the company is passionate about this game and truly believes in its success.First Impression: I admit before entering the game for the first time I had my doubts about it seriously being much better than the Deer Hunter series gameplay wise and graphically. WOW! Was I ever wrong? Once I wondered away from the starting lodge and into the woods I found myself inspecting all the elements of the environment and vegetation. Astounded at the amount of progress that was made graphically for a hunting simulation. Then I hear a mule deer buck call off in the distance breaking me from my trance. Once that bucked stepped into view the rest is history. Here I am now in 2014 still actively playing the game nearly every day since its release in 2009 currently with 1057 hours of gameplay time.Free to play: theHunter is Free to Play. This is a very touchy subject for players. It does have 2 species on 2 reserves that are free to hunt. The mule deer and the Cottontail Rabbit can be hunted on 2 different reserves after completing missions for GM$ to buy the single shot 12 gauge shotgun. The downside is that you will also need to purchase the ammunition. My opinion is that if it can be purchased by EM$ or GM$ then ammunition should be unlimited. theHunter does offer very limited free content of the game. On the other side you have to take into account that the game is continuously in development with a team devoted to it. Which requires a steady flow of income.Membership: theHunter offers 3 basic memberships for 3, 6 and 12 months. 3 package memberships for 3 (Wayfarer), 6 (Pathfinder) and 12 (Trailrunner) months, each with a selection of equipment. Many argue that the cost of the game is high. Here I strongly disagree. In reality even with the membership cost and further micro transactions the game does not cost any more than a normal gaming entertainment budget. Most subscription based online games cost anywhere from $10-19/m, a cost of $120-144/y. Even console games that are released regularly will cost $45-60 for each new game and are released about once a year. The cheapest basic membership at theHunter costs $9.99 for 3 months which is $3.33/m or $39.96/y. A nice difference versus paying $45-144/y. Now take the Trailrunner membership, theHunter’s most expensive option. It is 12 months of membership and starter items for $49.99 which is $4.17/m. At least $5 cheaper than most subscription games per month and at least $70/y. Once your 12 month Trailrunner membership runs out you can renew with a 12 month basic membership for $34.99 which is $2.92/m. That is atleast $10 cheaper than a new console game or atleast $85 cheaper than 1 year for most other sub based games. The amount difference you saved playing theHunter versus the newest console game or most other sub based games can be used to buy any extra items you may want to spice up your inventory with. You can either play theHunter cheaper than most other games, just about the same cost or even more. It is all up to you as a player to decide.Weapons: There are 15 rifles, 5 handguns, 6 shotguns, 4 bows, a crossbow and a muzzleloader. All have scopes and sights that can be fitted to them. You really only need 1-2 weapons to ethically hunt every species. Buying more just adds variety to your arsenal. So do not be alarmed by these posts saying you need $300 to purchase all weapons. All of the weapons are not necessary to have but an option.Clothing: Some clothing is purely cosmetic meaning that it offers no such advantage while other clothing such as the Basic Set variants, Boone & Crockett, Army Set, Trapper Set, Doc Monsignor Set and the Ghillie Suit offer different advantages over certain or all species for different types of vegetation. Those advantages are Scent reduction, Visual reduction and Sound reduction. Not every set is a must have. Hunting close range is where these specialized clothing sets have the biggest advantage. When purchasing clothing sets I can highly recommend the Bundles section in the store for a discounted price.Equipment: Here you have a good variety of items at your disposal. Optics such as binoculars, range finders and a compact digital camera. Consumables such as wind indicator, scent eliminator, camping supplies (for fast travel to tents) and first aid kits. theHunter does have some dangerous game that will charge you. These are moose, feral hog, wild boar, black bear and brown bear. If attacked you will need a first aid kit to continue or you must travel to the nearest lodge or tent (if you have camping supplies).Play modes: theHunter has Single player and Multiplayer. You can create a multiplayer game for you and up to 7 of your friends to hunt together. There are missions you can complete for GM$. These can be completed in both single player and multiplayer.Competitions: theHunter offers competitions for every species in the game, except for Cottontail Rabbit. Competitions for new species are introduced a short time after the species release. Competitions are for both Single and Multiplayer. They all offer a small amount of EM$ and a trophy for finishing in 1st, 2nd or 3rd . Special events are run giving awards for the top 10 finishers. During certain holidays special run events or missions will be run. There are also private hosted competitions by members of theHunter, myself included. These generally are listed in the Competition forum at theHunter forums. These offer better pay-outs for the top finishers than the official competitions. Some useful places to find these private competitions are here: http://thehuntercomps.se/, {LINK REMOVED}Derpy Competitions and White Out Hunting[www.whiteouthunting.enjin.com].The Community: The player community is very friendly and helpful. Players have devoted a lot of personal time into the forums, theHunter Wiki and other fan pages. Theres alot helpful game information in the forums, the wiki, guides, videos and some even do live streaming of the game.The Development Team: Last but definitely not least the development team. This group of men and women have done an outstanding job bringing us the best hunting simulation there is and will continue to do so. They keep us updated weekly as to what is happening behind the scenes. Each week there is also a game update. This can be bug fixes or larger updates such as new items, species or reserves. Proof that our support is being put to good use.I hope this will help you to decide to stay and help support a great game despite many negative reviews it has received from the Steam community. Use what is given as free content to help you further decide if this game is worth it. Every one of the 1000+ hours and the money I have invested in the game has been well worth it.

content:
2, 2014
												I believe this game is for a certain type of player. First if you are impatient this game is not for you. If you crave constant action then you probably won't like this. If you don't want to spend any money then this is not for you. If you like to hunt, enjoy the reward of patiently stalking and killing something, have some money to spend; then you will probably like this.I'll comment first about the gameplay then about the pricing of the "free to play" in the second/third paragraph.The game has a slower pace to it, I'll give an example of a typical hunt for me. I spawn at a lodge and load up my equipment in my inventory; I'm hunting whitetail and maybe turkey today so I want my shotgun for versatility and bow for stealth, I could take my .243 rifle but I prefer the shotgun. It's early in the morning and I can see the misty dew settling on the grass plains. The air feels fresh as I slowly wander about looking for my sign. A red tracker mark over some footprints point me in the way of a deer and I walk after it. I want to rush and sprint but I must be patient lest I spook it away. Droppings indicate to me how far it might be, more footprints help me close in on it when I hear the grunt of a buck. I crouch down and sit. I could stalk it down, but I'd rather the deer come to me. I pull out my deer call and mimic the sound of a doe to the open air. A call from the buck responds in kind. The bucks grunts get louder and louder, I know which way he's coming from but there is too much brush in the way. I lay down amongst some grass to make my profile even smaller and wait for him to reveal himself. At last I spot him standing tall and he calls out for the doe in my trap. He is still too far out so I maneuver onto a small hill for a better vantage while he gently and slowly walks in. I watch him closely and load a shell of buckshot into my shotgun, he suspects nothing. He has a decent set of antlers, nothing special, but he carries himself as a king. Still, I know my role as assassin well and wait for him to close in  enough to see the grain of his antlers. Finally he stops before me and raises his head high as I hold my breath to steady the shot. Silence tells him nothing until a cacophonous blast reverberates through the air and scares away any nearby animals from the king as he falls to his knees and lands his face in the dirt. I pull out my huntermate, snap a trophy shot, and claim my work. Walking away I eject the spent shell and load another, there's plenty out there yet on the reserve today. The game looks pretty good and I can tell they put quite a bit of work into the environment. There are a few bugs that happen in multiplayer but otherwise the game itself is very good.Now for the reveal of the abnormal market. Since this appears to be a niche game, they have decided to get it paid for in a way, I think, most steam gamers aren't accustomed to. The free-to-play isn't, its more of a demo really. When you first start out you can only hunt mule dear and rabbit with your one .243 rifle, and shooting rabbit with your rifle will give you disqualifying kills. If you want to hunt everything then you can get, at minimum, a 10$ membership which is good for 3 months. On top of that you'll want calls, other weapons, equipment, which all cost real money. To further the currency explaination: The game has paid for currency (em$) and earned currency (gm$). Em$ is a cent to cent ratio, 100em$ is $1.00. Almost every weapon is 4-6 dollars, yeah, I know. Each call is over a dollar, clothes costs a few bucks (don't buy individually, get bundles), stands, blinds, other items are all going to be 4 dollars or so. In other words, you can easily spend more than a triple-A $60 title. In other words, if you put money down, spend smart (research stuff) and make sure you're getting what you want.Gm$ are earned by doing missions and are terribly underutilized and overpriced in the store. I do enjoy doing the missions, a little extra goal and challenge to a hunt, not too hard to accomplish. With gm$ you can buy one single shot shotgun for 6200 (I have it, I like it) otherwise you can get sprays to attract animals or bait and that is pretty much it. You would think at least some clothing but nope. You can get animal licenses individually with gm$ but its priced so high for a beginner its not worth it (1800 gm$ for 1 day of turkey hunting). I sort of understand why everything is so expensive compared to other games but I don't agree with it.A little more about my experience that may be helpful. I hunted with a friend who picked up items so I didn't have to get everything, he got a bunch of mallard gear, I got a bunch of geese gear. I only hunt with the .243 rifle (given for free) which is good for most deer and coyote and fox. A 12 gauge shotgun, which can shoot anything except birds with slugs and birdshot can shoot those (you get three kinds of shells and it replenishes for every trip). So yes, with one shotgun you can shoot any animal in the game, given somewhat limited range. Finally a compound bow which is great for stealth and when you have multiple animals coming as it won't scatter them like a gun. So my method is very up close and personal usually but only took the purchase of the bow; the pump-action shotgun came with a membership bundle. If you want to hunt big game with a rifle get something up in the .300 caliber range and you're good to go.So as a result: Good game for patient gamers who have decent income. Bad game for someone looking for an actual free-to-play game like War Thunder or LoL and/or doesn't like somewhat realistic hunting. Of course you can always try it out yourself. Do the tutorials when you start it up (Hunt Now -> Tutorials) Also read up on the wiki (thehunterwiki.com) has a lot of useful information. If you do decide to get into the game and put down money. I recommend one of the membership bundles, you get a lot more than getting it individually.If this review isn't helpful please comment why and I'll do my best to improve it with what you need to know.

number of helpful: 27 of 52 people (52%) found this review helpful3 people found this review funny
content:
4, 2015
												TheHunter, Why I enjoy this game.1- For everybody who appreciates realism, I belive this one is as close as it gets.2- A very mature community (usually older people who have the patientce to hunt, yes less than in real life but still this game  requires patience to bring home those beautiful animal trophies).3- The game is constantly updated and it keeps a very strong data base tracking every animal you hunted/spotted, every shot fired with each weapon so you can see how you are doing comparing to others not to mention that daily there are competitions with trophies and prizes.4- Beautiful graphics and sounds (especially when maxing graphics), makes you really feel like hiking in the wild.I would like to say a few words about why this game is unjustifiably "trashed" on steam.1- Notice, that absolutly 99.9% of all negative reviews are by people who barely played and just seem not to understand the bussiness model, no single negative comment is actually made about the game it self.2- The bussiness model of this game is different and it requires understanding.Bussiness model:1- As a "Free to Play" what you get is a limited experience of being able to visit all the maps  but to hunt only 2  species (Mule Deer, Cottontail Rabbit). Clearly this will not last you for hundreds of hours but you must consider this as a 5-10 hours of "demo" that will show you wether you would like the game or not.2- TheHunter is constantly being updated (Its the same game from 2009) so the bussiness model here is a subscription bussiness model. In reallity depending on the time you commit to 3-12 monthes you can pay as little as 3$ for a month (35$ per year).3- The items/ gear that is sold in thehunter is also sold for real money, you must consider this as DLCs (steam languge).4- Even if you absolutly want to a lot of new content yearly it shouldnt cost you more than 50$ per year.In case you are intrested in trying:1- Just download the game.2- Tune up graphics in settings to max (relative to your rig ofc.)3- Start and finish the tutorial.4- Start / Join a hunt in "Logger's Point" and go on tracking and hunting "Mule Deers" and "Cottontail Rabbits"5- After a few hours you will see if the game is for you ;)

content:
4, 2015
												Note this is not a free 2 play game and the free 2 play content is limited in scope to the point where it is just a demo. This game is a game that takes time and some investment to enjoy, first off I suggest buying a membership after trying the game, this will allow you to hunt all game. I have a Trailrunner (1 year) membership, this gives you a few guns some calls and a membership, also the membership gives you 3 replenishing boxes of ammo after every hunt, so you hunt use it all quit start a new hunt and it will be available again. I also bought every call, and some set up bundles, but that was after around 40 hours in the game. The graphics are great and immerse you into these beautiful reserves. The tracking and spotting of animals is excellent. Animals have a nice variety in size and antlers. There also rare coloration differences and for some deer non typical antlers. There are dogs for waterfowl and they are a nice premium item. There is also bow hunting which involves stalking and getting up close to your prey, an intense and fun experience.Ok enough rambling, basically this game, is more like an iracing you need to narrow what you want to hunt or do or be prepared to spend more than what an average game costs. More on hunting on a budget, pick a style not species say bow hunting, competition hunting, waterfowl, big game etc. Then buy some the items that help you hunt in that style, for bow hunting maybe some camo and an upgraded bow, competition, the calls can be key, waterfowl a blind and decoys, big game calls and a nice rifle. So it can be played on a budget but to be the best at hunting everything can get expensive, now the setups mentioned above can be had for around $20 - $30 a piece and this is on the high end. This is not a free to play game but a hardcore hunting simulation, but if you find what you want to hunt through watching videos or trying to hunt them you can immerse yourself even on a budget.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
6, 2014
												WHAT IS THE HUNTER?The hunter is a simulation game based on real life hunting, it requires patience and it's time consuming but rewarding in the end. there is something about that feeling of stalking your pray knowing that one simple sound may spooke the price buck, but if your quiet and careful a well place shot to a vital organ may kill it instantly and you go home with a trophy or you can miss and track him back again all depends how you aproach the sitation.The world is expansive, lot of walking but fear not aoutowalk option is availive!!, there are a big number of different variaty of animals from a simple mule deer to white tail,brown bears,moose,canadian goose among many others, not to mention weapons like hunting rifles (of course), bows, shotguns, revolvers, special rifles, as well as clothing and hunting tools. truly in an immersice world with a lot in your hands to choose and make your simulation a better experience.IS IT FREE TO PLAY OR PAY TO WIN?The game is free to play with its restrictions, currently you can can hunt two animals for free, mule deers and rabbits (male & female), you can roam and explore any map but the animals are restiricted to a membership or hunting permit found at this link.http://www.thehunter.com/#bank/membershipsplease read carefully the perks of each memberships and permits before proceeding to purchase. Ladies and genteleman it is important to consider the efforert of the developers and the fact that they need to gain something out of this,j ust as if you would invent something would you give it fully for free??...the answer is no! lets not be naive nor insult our inteligence, if you like this game support the developers. they are not forcing you to buy it it's all up to you., you want to spend 10 dollars or euros or 50 or more it's up tp you, in the end you make your experience, you decide what to buy. if you dont like the game dont ruin the experience for others just because you dont like the transaction system, act as you would like others to act towards you and put yourself in the developers and creators shoes before saying anything.IS IT WORTH INCESTING IN THE GAME OR PLAYING IT?yes!, if you agree, like this kind of games and can most importantly run this game then it's worth it, but i suggest you give it a try first, play it a couple of days and see if you dont get bored with the basic free membership, if you then really like it and want to expand your hunting experience, please support the developers and most importantly enjoy the game.Thanks everyone for taking the time to read this review i hope this helps in making a better hunter out of you, see you on the reserves lol.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
er 23, 2016
												Although you do need to invest some money to get the most enjoyment out of this game as you can, it is definitely worth it. As an avid hunter for over ten years now, I never thought I would find a video game that could come close to what the great outdoors are like. With each and every update, TheHunter inches closer and closer to this mark - actually it hit that mark a long time ago and just gets closer towards absolute perfection.The only thing a person really needs to buy is a weapon, or two, or ten...or thirty. Just so you have the ability to hunt every animal, you need compatible weapons. If you do missions and grind a bit, you can do this completely Free to Play - but it can be discouraging and seeing a large or trophy animal (or even a rare variant) appear before you and knowing you cannot take that trophy due to license restrictions would be disheartening - so really the only money anyone should spend would be on a subscription (which for a year is well-priced in my opinion, especially if you do the Trailblazer pack that comes with plenty of weapons and camouflage).At this point it just becomes a game you paid once for and it's like you're buying DLC if you really like it. You have the weapons and gear permanently, and if you play that year you purchased you should have enough GM$ to renew licenses and ammunition.On top of everything, it's MULTIPLAYER. Single lobbies do exist, but being able to hunt with a friend and scout together or compete for the largest trophy, it's just loads of fun. Even counting down from 3-1 so you both can take down trophies simultanaeously...it's just great overall.

This game is listed as free to play on Steam; but it really isn't. There's better titles out there (and one I really liked) that are worth the money. My opinion about this game isn't entirely focused on their bussiness model. The game needs a lot of improvements. Really. Both graphically and physics-engine related.**I don't even know how this game ended up on my library**Had the freemium bussiness model never existed, I'd have played this game without second thoughts.- I don't recommend this game as of now. Unless you want have some agony stuffed in your face three days from the day you registered.

content:
er 23, 2016
												Although you do need to invest some money to get the most enjoyment out of this game as you can, it is definitely worth it. As an avid hunter for over ten years now, I never thought I would find a video game that could come close to what the great outdoors are like. With each and every update, TheHunter inches closer and closer to this mark - actually it hit that mark a long time ago and just gets closer towards absolute perfection.The only thing a person really needs to buy is a weapon, or two, or ten...or thirty. Just so you have the ability to hunt every animal, you need compatible weapons. If you do missions and grind a bit, you can do this completely Free to Play - but it can be discouraging and seeing a large or trophy animal (or even a rare variant) appear before you and knowing you cannot take that trophy due to license restrictions would be disheartening - so really the only money anyone should spend would be on a subscription (which for a year is well-priced in my opinion, especially if you do the Trailblazer pack that comes with plenty of weapons and camouflage).At this point it just becomes a game you paid once for and it's like you're buying DLC if you really like it. You have the weapons and gear permanently, and if you play that year you purchased you should have enough GM$ to renew licenses and ammunition.On top of everything, it's MULTIPLAYER. Single lobbies do exist, but being able to hunt with a friend and scout together or compete for the largest trophy, it's just loads of fun. Even counting down from 3-1 so you both can take down trophies simultanaeously...it's just great overall.

content:
r 2, 2014
												Well I'm pretty sure I played this game before, the first map looked very familiar, which was very discouraging as the last time I saw no animals at all.This time I played the tutorials that weren't there before and they went well. Then I went off to try and hunt.Found a bunch of deer, yet every shot I took my gun lowered and I got a message saying I have no license.After a bit of investigating I found out all about the supposed licensing. The "free" part consists of 1 type of deer and a type of bird.Went and looked further and decided I'll try the $10US membership so I got all licenses.After that I went back and things went down hill. Spent quite a few hours playing and the more time went by the less animals I found. Some times I'd be following a track and suddenly the "huntermate" would turn me around or loop over the previously found track. Other time the track I was looking for wasn't actually in the direction I was pointed and other times it'd just go cold out of nowhere. Some "mate" that is.On the way back to the camp I see a turkey out of nowhere and so shoot it, to which I get told off for an "unpermitted hit" for using the wrong ammo. So I leave and go to the shop to find all the ammo costs more real money along with every other item.Going to uninstall this, and if I could I'd have my $10 back too.Steam should also remove the "free to play tag" since 99% isn't free.

content:
er 10, 2016
												I obviously have enjoyed this game for some time. It is the most realistic hunting game on the market. Real hunters will have a true advantage over gamers that don't hunt. The graphics and sceneries are beautiful. 37 different species and 11 reserves to hunt and the devs are always working on more (weekly updates). The subscription is very cheap (around 3 dollars a month). It's relaxing and exciting at times. Tons of competitions and missions to earn in game money and trophies. For free players, there are 3 species you can always hunt (Whitetail, pheasants and european rabbits) and they rotate 2 other species every week for you to hunt for free. You can also join multiplayer games to hunt with your buddies. It's deffinetly worth checking out. If you would like info on how I pay for my items and membership without spending my own money, please check my profile.

content:
r 9, 2014
												I am an avid hunter in Northern Arizona. This game makes me feel like I am actually hunting that nice big mule deer. But the game is not free to play. When you get it you are only allowed to hunt mule deer and rabbit in only one area of the game. If you want to hunt other animals you have to pay for licenses, and the weapons to hunt those animals. To advertise a game like this as a free to play is wrong. It should be advertised as a free to win game as the only way to get that big whitetail, moose, or elk is to buy a membership, then spend cash for coins to buy bigger and better guns. I recommend the game if you like great graphics and the feeling of outdoors, but not as a hunting game. Buy one of Cabela's games. Everything is included and you don't have to spend over 200.00 to get great stuff.

content:
er 24, 2014
												theHunter is one of the most enjoyable and most beautiful hunting games available at this time IMO of course. The realistic aspect is not to far extreme where you find yourself waiting a whole day to bag and tag a single animal, but at the same time not at all arcade-y where you can gun down 5 deer in a matter of seconds. The pace of this game is rather rewarding is the sense of accomplishment when it come to the hunt.The main complaint that many have is there price structure. Yes, it can get expensive purchasing all that is available for this game. In fact If I recall correctly that if you happen to buy everything all at once (not including consumables and a ammo), you are looking at about a $600 price tag.  Yes, a lot of money, but at the same time compare that to Train Simulator 2015 which holds a price tag well over double of theHunter for all of its DLC. This game should not be considered Free-To-Play, but rather Free-To-Test or simple know it as a Demo since you are only allowed to hunt 1 species of deer (Mule Deer) on 1 reserve (Loggers Point). Also some have stated this is a Pay-To-Win game. Far from it IMO. Buying the ingame equipment and such doesnt make you a better hunter than everyone else. You just have more options to hunt and hunt with. Purchasing items in this game is like buying DLC for any other game in the long run. You do get to keep them forever minus consumables, but those can even be purchased with the ingame currency, gm$ which are earned buy completing ingame missions.At this current time, theHunter is being offered on the Steam Holiday Sale (2014) for 20% off on bundles.  If you have any  form of interest and are willing to support a game that actually works vs. the latest and greatest AAA titles that havent been, now would be a great time to purchase. The largest bundle is currently going for 39.99.  This includes an annual membership that alone cost 35 dollars during the normal time of the year, but also included in this bundle is $85 worth of gear that will allow you to hunt everything and anything under the sun within this game.  Even when the sale lets up, a price tag of 49.99 is not bad. $35 for the annual and $15  for the additional $85 worth of gear.All and all, I recommend this game to those that enjoy a good hunt and are will to invest a little money (the bundle) into it as you would any other game title that isnt listed as Free-To-Play. After all... games dont make themselves.

r 24, 2014
												I really, really, REALLY wanted to like this game. I saw it and it's graphics and downloaded it instantly...I'm not one to judge a game about it's graphics but these are simply beautiful. The UI looks nice and it seems fun...There is only one reason I have to give a negative review; MICROTRANSACTIONS! You can do almost nothing without paying money in real life. ry 4, 2015
												I won't argue the 'Free Play' ****, st*pid marketing trick doesn't mean bad game. Actually I found this game itself totally worth the $60. And there's a friendly community. But every time you play, you need to connect the official server (not Steam). After only about 1 hour's playing, I got a lot of so called 16002 error, can't play for several hours, quite frustrating. And the in-game purchase is ridiculous -I don't talk about membership, that's kind of acceptable to me- But after people already have had paid $60, why? Did anyone know what DLC is for?A 70/100 game ruined by weird ideas and inadequate servers.Not recommended at current state.----------------------------------Feb 9 2016,The infamous 16002 error was gone. This is a good sign.BUT, my steam trail-runner pack is still not here, after I paid the price ONE WEEK ago. And the only answer I got from their customer service, was that they were looking into it. Still not recommended then. /shrug

content:
y 24, 2015
OverviewIm sorry theHunter, I played this game after playing the amazing theHunter: Primal, and the second I loaded up the game I was dissappointed. The UI looks crappy and movement seems to be much, much slower. If you think Im comparing it too much to Primal, then look at it this way. Movement is fairly slow in Primal, so in this one it feels like you are tip-toeing through the grass, even when you are running. Its also harmed by quite possibly the worst free 2 play business model I have ever seen. I just couldn't bring myself to play much of this game. However, I will say that when creating a profile with theHunter it is quite nice to pick an avatar for your character.Positive+ Character customisationNegative- Character Movement- Crappy looking UI- Hunting Licenses (Business Model)ConclusionI feel quite sad for having had to leave this review, quite simply because I love theHunter: Primal so much, it makes me feel grateful that it turned out so good, even in early access. You should definitley not download this game, it hardly even counts as f2p.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
er 17, 2014
												I've played a lot of Hunting Simulator games in my time and this one was by FAR the best one I've ever come across. There are plenty of animals (with great behavioral mechanics), weapons, levels, and good ol' trophy kill satisfaction to keep you occupied for a long time.Unfortunately the pay-forever-to-play business model ruins it. They took it way too seriously with the word 'simulator', meaning it simulates everything, even the crap parts of real hunting like having to fork out real money for temporary hunting licences.They argue that many people don't play a game for more than a year, hence the "justification" of having to pay the cost of a full-game every year. But I've been playing Deer Hunter 2005 since 2005 and thanks to this game's poor business model I'll still be playing it in 2015. That's the kind of decated fans they are turning off with this payment method.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
6, 2014
												The only hunting simulator worth playing out there at the moment!The Hunter couples gorgeous graphics and immersive sound design to create vast environments that feel real when you step into them, something that other hunting games out there just don’t replicate. Recent hunting games have been shoe-horning you down corridors while Ibex and Lions jump out onto your shotgun barrel. The Hunter gives you the opportunity to experience the journey, a complete hunting scenario: Listening out for calls, tracking, and observation, not just constantly providing a slurry of beautiful beasts to bludgeon.I believe the game suffers when informing new comers. I’d recommend checking out the wiki before jumping in as there are some rules for Guest players who haven’t purchased a membership regarding what you can hunt and where. I have all confidence in the Dev team though! They are constantly active and seem to value and utilise feedback. New content is always on the horizon whether it is new gear, weapons, species or reserves to hunt. The game also boasts a strong community to hunt alongside or against in an interesting array of hunting challenges.

content:
9, 2015
												So, I'm back, and this time, an in-depth (not really) review of thehunter. So, yes I know, microtransactions suck, but even if you pay the $15.00 fee for a license(3 months, I believe), you WILL enjoy this game. I happen to find the game really fun. I have decided to buy the $50.00 membership (12 months). The $15.00 and both, the $50.00 plan, come with weapons. The $15.00 comes with a little bit of stuff, but not a load. The $50.00 gives you a bow, two pistols, two shotguns, and two rifles (I may be wrong about that). They both, of course give you a license to hunt all animals and unlimited basic ammo. So if you really don't like the idea of the game, then maybe this will help you face the microtransactions, if you want to play, of course. Thanks for reading this review, this is my opinion of the game, I enjoy playing it, and have collected this informaton since the last time I wrote a review on this game.

content:
ry 3, 2016
												I played the Hunter well before it went to Steam and thoroughly enjoyed the game, even more so competitively hunting against other players I knew in multiplayer.  So many of the Steam reviews revolve around two themes:  this games isn't F2P, and it doesn't deliver instant gratification.There is no such thing as a free lunch.  I wonder how many of the negative reviewers have purchased premium time in WoT, WoW, AW, or War Thunder?  Or have spent $$$ on the Lowe in WoT?  Maybe a premium ship in WoW?  Of course you should feel entitled that they conform their payment model to other games, that bare very little simularity to what they have created. /sarcasm  This isn't an arcade game like a Cabellas special, it actually makes you have patience and some skill.  I think they know that the masses aren't going to find this title appealing, that it won't be Far Cry Primal.  If you want to participate in something unique, you have to pay the entrance fee.  The best part is that they have constantly expanded the content and listened to community feedback.  And when you start looking at the content, you start seeing that you don't need every piece of it to have fun.  You could hunt almost any animal in any reserve with a 12 gauge pump.  I personally like the classic muzzle loader.  I have a few guns and a bow, but they compliment what I like to hunt, as does my gear.  I don't have to have or expect all of the content.  The most important part is that license. $35 gets you 12 months to hunt any species.  That's not $14/month for premium time in some other games.  I think people are conveniently ignoring that they can selectively buy the content and experience they want.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
, 2016
												I have played this game for more than 1000 hours, just not through steam. The game is beautiful and probably the best hunting simulator you'll come across for a very long time. Some new players won't enjoy it because they don't realize that the game is not meant to be played as COD or Battlefield, and you'll have a hard time getting alot of harvests if you sprint around with your rifle when trying to find animals.The biggest problem for new players though, is the awful payment model. You need to buy membership or licenses to be able to hunt all the animals, which costs real money. You also have to buy in-game currency to buy new weapons through the store, which is the only way you'll to be able to take ethical shots on all species. You can buy membership packages (bundles) which comes with discounted weapons and equipment, but it won't take long before you wish you had more callers, camos, tents, weapons, you name it, even if you bought the 1year membership bundle. There are alot of items in the game, and pretty much all of it will cost you real money, aswell as being somewhat expensive compared to most other F2P games.All this taken into consideration, I still love the game, simply because I feel the gameplay is worth the money you need to spend on it to enjoy it. If you are looking for a good hunting simulator, this is your game, but you will have to be willing to spend quite a bit of money on it to be able to enjoy it to it's full potential. If you are just looking for a F2P time-waster, then this game is very likely not something you want to spend much time on.
